PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition

A humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Attention is drawn to Australia's increasing role in the militarisation of the Pacific region and in particular to the current Government-led arms export drive.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: CPI Relativity
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that pensioners are being burdened with an increase in the cost of living and are receiving no compensation for it. FAMILY LAW AMENDMENT BILL (NO. 2) 1991

This Bill implements the recommendation of the First Report of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act that, as a matter of priority, the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to fix a maximum age of 70 years for judges of the Family Court.

When the Family Law Act was enacted in 1975 there was no maximum age for judges appointed to the Family Court. Judges had life tenure in accordance with section 72 of the Constitution, as it then stood.

The 1976 report on Retiring Ages for Commonwealth Judges of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recommended that a compulsory retiring age should be introduced for all federal judges. The Committee recommended that the appropriate maximum age for justices of the High Court should be 70, and that, after an appropriate amendment to the Constitution, Parliament should legislate to prescribe a maximum age of 65 for judges of other federal courts. The proposal to amend the Constitution to provide a compulsory retiring age for all federal judges was accepted in the 1977 referendum.

Following the referendum in 1977, section 72 of the Constitution was amended to provide a maximum age for federal judges of 70 and to provide that Parliament may make a law fixing a maximum age for judges, of a court created by Parliament, at less than 70 years. The only law made, pursuant to section 72, fixing a maximum age for judges at less than 70 years is in relation to the Family Court.

Section 23A of the Family Law Act 1975, which fixes the maximum age for judges of the Family Court at 65, was inserted in the Act in 1977 following the constitutional amendment. At that time the provision of a maximum retiring age of 65 was a reflection of community concerns that Family Court judges should be aware of and keep abreast of current social values and attitudes and took into account the demanding and arduous nature of some, if not all, family law disputes.

The Joint Select Committee believes that the reasons for fixing a retiring age of 65 for the Family Court are no longer valid. The Committee concurred with the views of the Family Law Council that it is important for Family Court judges to be aware of current social values and that there would not be a substantial difference, in this area, between judges who were 65 and those who were 70.

This amendment will not require judges to remain on the Court past the age of 65. Judges will still be able to retire at an earlier age, and if over age 60 will be entitled to receive the maximum judicial pension if they have served 10 years or more as a judge.

For some time criticism has been made of the nature of the Family Court and its operations. For example, in 1985 Chief Justice Gibbs made some criticisms of the specialist nature of the Family Court in his address to the 23rd Australian Legal Convention on the State of the Australian Judicature.

His Honour noted the limited scope of the jurisdiction of the Court and questioned whether the work of the Court required strengthening. He also suggested that the limited scope of the jurisdiction of the Family Court was unlikely to attract lawyers who might be expected to be appointed to Supreme Courts or the Federal Court.

I believe the experience of the Family Court over the past 15 years has demonstrated the wisdom which led to its establishment. The past 15 years have not been easy. Nevertheless the Court has maintained the highest standards in the administration of justice. Since its inception in 1976 the Court has attracted judges and other officers of a high standing in the legal profession.

In recent years the Government has taken some initiatives to ensure that the Court continues to have the capacity to attract high calibre lawyers. For example, following the recommendations of the 1987 report of the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission on the Australian Judiciary the Government legislated to increase the jurisdiction of the Court.

The Family Court of Australia (Additional Jurisdiction and Exercise of Powers) Act 1988 provided a mechanism whereby the Family Court could exercise jurisdiction under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977, the Bankruptcy Act 1966, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Trade Practices Act 1974. Further, Commonwealth and State cross-vesting legislation allows the Court to exercise the jurisdiction of the Federal Court and various State Supreme Courts in appropriate matters.

Following this increase in jurisdiction the Government legislated to bring the salaries of Family Court judges into line with Federal Court judges. The amendment to the Family Law Act to increase the maximum retiring age of judges from 65 to 70 years will ensure that the terms and conditions of judges of the Family and Federal Courts are equivalent.

This Bill amends the Family Law Act by repealing section 23A which fixed the maximum retiring age at 65. The provisions of section 72 of the Constitution, providing a maximum age of 70 for federal judges, will apply to all future appointments to the Family Court. When the legislation is passed the existing judges whose commissions are limited until age 65 will be given new commissions in terms of the new age limit.

The Bill also amends section 41 of the Family Law Act to provide that judges appointed to State Family Courts are permitted to hold office until age 70. This is to ensure that judges of the Family Court of Western Australia, the only State Family Court established under section 41, may also hold office until age 70.

NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY
AMENDMENT BILL 1991
This Bill contains several proposals which are designed to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the operations of the National Crime Authority.

The major reform contained in the Bill will prevent the disclosure of the existence of process issued by the NCA in the course of its investigations. It will also prevent disclosure of any information about the reference, the investigation or any hearings or proceedings to which the process relates. Previously some recipients of NCA summonses or notices, such as financial institutions, felt obliged to inform their clients of the receipt of these documents. This has resulted in suspects being alerted to NCA investigations and concealing or destroying evidence or going into hiding. The amendment will help to prevent this happening again, and will clarify the legal position of these institutions.

In addition to this, the amendment will also serve to protect the reputation of suspects at a time when the allegations have not been properly investigated. The recipient of the summons or notice has to be given sufficient details about the suspects so that they can determine what information is required. The potential for damage to the reputation of these people through disclosure of the existence of the summons or notice could be significant.

It is for these reasons that the decision to make a notation restricting disclosure can only be made where the NCA is satisfied that failure to prohibit disclosure might prejudice the safety, reputation or fair trial of a person, the effectiveness of an investigation, or it is otherwise in the public interest.

The provision has been designed in a way which is consistent with the NCA's desire to be more open and accountable. Instead of a blanket prohibition, this provision will only apply where, subject to the criteria I have just mentioned, a decision is made to restrict disclosure in a particular case.
It is important to note that the provision contains a number of other safeguards:
Under the amendment, disclosure will always be permitted to allow the person served with the NCA process to obtain legal advice or legal aid in relation to the process or matter.

Further, where process is served on a legal practitioner, disclosure can be made to allow the practitioner to comply with any legal duties of disclosure arising from the professional relationship with the client, or to obtain instructions in relation to legal professional privilege.
Depending on the particular case, disclosure may also be permitted in other circumstances specified in the notation on the summons or notice.

A further safeguard is that the prohibition will only remain in force for a maximum period of five years or until the investigation is concluded, whichever occurs first. If the investigation is concluded and the NCA has been advised by the prosecuting authority that no prosecution will be undertaken, or there is no evidence of an offence, or in other cases criminal proceedings arising from the investigation have been commenced, then the prohibition will no longer apply. Where this occurs the NCA will be obliged to notify those to whom the summons or notice was addressed.

The NCA is giving a higher priority to the co-ordination of efforts by State and Commonwealth law enforcement agencies against white collar and corporate crime. It is evident from past experience that these complex investigations also lead to the disclosure of major tax evasion, proceeds of crime and money laundering offences. White collar crime transcends State boundaries and effective control can only be achieved by the co-ordinated national activities of agencies such as the NCA. The power to obtain documents had proven to be a powerful tool in NCA investigations of fraud and related criminal activity, which are often document based. This amendment will improve the effectiveness of investigations in these important areas.

The Bill also contains three more minor amendments which will help to improve the functioning of the NCA. The first will enable the NCA to apply for a warrant of apprehension where a witness fails or refuses to appear at a hearing. Currently, such witnesses may be fined or imprisoned under the Act, however, the current penalties do not in themselves ensure attendance at a hearing. Access to a warrant for the arrest of such people would assist the effective conduct of NCA hearings.

The second of these will allow the Chairman of the NCA, rather than the Attorney-General, to appoint counsel to assist the Authority. This amendment is in line with recent Government moves to devolve such powers to authority heads to improve efficiency.

Finally, the amendment will authorise the NCA to inform relevant members of the Inter-Governmental Committee about general investigations being conducted in their particular State or Territory. At present there is a cumbersome procedure whereby the information has to first pass to the Commonwealth Minister before dissemination to the State or Territory Minister. It is the view of the Government, the NCA and all the States and Territories represented on the Inter-Governmental Committee that the States and Territories current access to information regarding references and special investigations be extended to include general investigations and to improve accountability.
I believe this Bill contains important reforms which will improve the effectiveness of the NCA as a national law enforcement body.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
HEARING SERVICES BILL 1991

The Bill before the Senate provides for the establishment of the Hearing Services Authority from 1 July 1992. This Bill gives effect to Cabinet's Decision of October last year that the National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) Hearing Services Program become a statutory authority, to be known as Australian Hearing Services.

The Bill will repeal the Acoustic Laboratories Act 1948 and amend section 9A of the National Health Act 1953, to bring the delivery of hearing services under one piece of legislation. Some may ask what changes will eligible clients experience? I can assure you that eligible clients will experience enhanced quality, cost effective, timely and relevant hearing services, both rehabilitation and hearing impairment prevention.
The new legislation will require the Authority to consult with relevant Government, business, commercial, industry, and consumer bodies in delivering services to eligible clients.

There will be no change to eligibility under the new Act--the Authority will continue to provide hearing rehabilitation services to Department of Social Security pensioners with a Pensioner Health Benefits Card and their dependants, Veterans' Affairs pensioners, anyone under the age of 21 years, people referred by Australian Defence Forces, Comcare, the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and the Australian Government Health Service. These services will include hearing loss assessment, the selection and fitting of appropriate hearing aids and devices and counselling at no charge to the client. It is only in respect to the repair and maintenance of hearing aids and devices and for the annual supply of batteries that clients, other than those in receipt of the Family Allowance Supplement and children of eligible clients, will continue to be required to make a small contribution. The Department of Veterans' Affairs will cover veterans for this cost.

The reorganisation of NAL as a statutory authority represents just one part of the reforms for the delivery of services to public interest clients who have a hearing impairment and who would but for this service not be able to afford the hearing aids and devices supplied by the private sector. It was for this, among other reasons, that the Government decided last year, not to follow the Industry Commission's recommendation that the whole hearing services market be opened up to two way competition.

Senators will be pleased to hear that considerable progress has been made with the joint venture between NAL and its commercial partner, Australian Hearing Aids (AHA). AHA is a joint venture between the Commonwealth (NAL) and AHA (which is a joint venture between Crystalaid Pty Ltd., a wholly owned Australian company and Ascom, a Swiss communications consortium) for the design, development and supply of the third generation of programmable hearing aids to NAL's clients and for exports markets in Asia, the United States and Europe.

This arrangement was possible because of the high international regard for the National Acoustic Laboratories and the Government's Hearing Services Program. It means that NAL will be able to supply world leading programmable hearing products to eligible clients from 1 January 1993. The establishment of NAL as a statutory authority underpins this arrangement.

One of the objectives of the Authority will be to participate, as far as is practicable, in promoting and establishing export markets for the jointly designed and developed hearing products. From this NAL stands to earn royalties from both the hearing aids and remote control units sold overseas. The government has been guaranteed minimum royalties of $2.6 million on all exports with projected royalties of over $9 million over the period of the contract.

As with many Government services some may consider this scheme excessive in the current economic climate, however, when one considers that nearly one in every ten Australians has a hearing impairment and that this ratio increases to one in every three people over the age of 65 years, then this more than justifies the need for a readily accessible and affordable program to assist those people.

The Government's NAL Hearing Services Program employs a team of highly trained and caring people, including university trained audiologists, some of whom specialise in either paediatric or adult services, technicians and administrative staff to ensure that eligible clients receive the level of service they require to enable them to communicate effectively in their everyday life. These services are delivered through a network of over 100 permanent and visiting NAL Hearing centres to ensure that all clients receive the same level of service across Australia.

NAL provides a comprehensive hearing health care program which is aimed at improving the quality of life for many pensioners who could otherwise be cut off from everyday life. The services provided by NAL also target children to ensure that their early development and learning is not impeded by their hearing impairment. NAL currently sees some 200,000 hearing impaired people. Last financial year NAL assessed some 50,000 new pensioners, veterans and children and fitted a total of 80,069 hearing aids. NAL's technicians repair about 270,000 hearing aids and devices each year.

The Bill does not alter the delivery of services to NAL's traditional hearing impaired clients, it simply makes changes to the administrative and operational aspects of the Program. The provision of hearing rehabilitation services to the traditional clients of NAL, including the fitting of appropriate hearing aids and devices, their maintenance and repair as well as batteries will continue to be provided by the Authority.

Another of the Authority's major activities will be research into hearing loss, hearing assessment and rehabilitation, hearing loss prevention and the effects of noise on people. A further activity for the Authority, which fits with its more commercial orientation, will be the hearing impairment prevention services provided by NAL. These activities fit well with the Government's overall objective of promoting better health in the community.

The new organisational arrangements for the delivery of hearing services to eligible clients set out in this Bill will see the appointment of a Board of Management which will report direct to the Minister. Members of this Board will be by Ministerial appointment and will consist of representatives from business and consumer organisations as well as the General Manager of the Authority.

The Board of Management of the Authority will, in accordance with the legislation, develop and operate under a Corporate Plan that sets the financial and operational targets for the Authority. As with all Government bodies and programs the Authority will have to perform against set targets and performance indicators.

The day to day operations of the Authority will be managed by a General Manager and the organisation will be restructured to facilitate these arrangements. The General Manager will also be appointed by the Minister. Staff of the Authority will continue to be appointed and employed under the Public Service Act.

The Authority will continue to operate under a Group 2 Trust Account, which was established on 1 July 1991. All monies and payment of all expenditures and disbursements relating to the Authority's operations will pass through this account. The Authority will also be subject to the same reporting requirements in relation to estimates and receipts of expenditure for each financial year, as any government body. Similarly, the Authority will be subject to the Audit Act and its reporting mechanisms as with any statutory body.

Under the new arrangements the Authority will continue to be primarily budget funded with monies being appropriated to the Authority by the Parliament. Although the Authority will be exempted from taxation, including payroll and sales tax, it will be required to pay customs duty, as it currently does.

Provision is made in the Bill for the levying of charges for products, services and facilities. Such charges will be set by regulation as is currently the case for any fees or charges levied by NAL. The Authority can enter into contractual arrangements up to $1 million without the approval of the Minister, but must have ministerial approval for any contract above this amount or for the sale or acquisition of property.

The rights of clients are protected by the inclusion in the Bill of both independent internal review, by the General Manager and external review of decisions by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal affecting the rights of clients, including the imposition of charges.

The Government's endeavours to streamline the operations of NAL has already borne fruit, with the introduction of computer systems and dramatic reductions in waiting times in all Hearing Centres. As a statutory authority, NAL will have the flexibility to achieve further improvements in the cost and timeliness of its services, and as a bonus will have low cost state-of-the-art hearing aids for Australians together with technology transfer and export earnings.

Article 23 states:

Certainly the Government has not been uncritical of aspects of the population program in China. They are about the Congress of the United States of America. We all know that there is a campaign running through UNFPA, IPPF and other international population control programs to get money from the United States Congress and the EC. I heard it when I was in Europe just a couple of weeks ago. There is an enormous push to get academics and others to make sure that there is more money paid by taxpayers throughout the world to population control organisations such as UNFPA and IPPF.

As I have said before in debates in this chamber, poverty is political and if we put our eggs in this basket, as it were, we are going down the track of violations of human rights and we will not rectify the problems of poverty. Secondly, and incidentally, I should indicate that whilst Dr Hull has received all this money his wife, Dr Valerie Hull, who is head of the relevant section of AIDAB, also received a contract from AIDAB to do a population kit for members of parliament which infringed human rights questions.

I do not really care what happens in the political area; that is up for grabs. Politics is up for grabs. But we are dealing with important questions of human rights and I believe it is important for the Department and for the Government to ensure that when they get advice on and assessments are made on human rights they obtain information from people who are objective and able to assist them from a principled background. I wonder whether Dr Hull's contracts were supported by the human rights section of the Department.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Harradine knows that on this issue we have fundamental disagreements in terms of policy approach and perspective. Equally, I have difficulty in accepting otherwise than at its face value the piece of work on recent population policy in China that Dr Hull did on commission from AIDAB as a prelude to the human rights delegation's visit, which report was made available to Senator Harradine last night. That report will be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —-No.
—-I am told that it was. The report is entitled Recent Population Policy in China.
—-That was the document presented to the China delegation, was it?

—-Yes. With minor editing changes only, I am told, this was the work that was done on commission from AIDAB, specifically in the context of the impending visit of the human rights delegation. It will be published as soon as the process works itself out. So there is no gap between any of this material in terms of what was privately made available to the delegation and what will be, in due course, in the public domain. The time delays will be the normal delays that occur in this respect.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the content of this particular report, it must speak for itself, as the parliamentary delegation's own report must speak for itself. It is a report to me, but not one that I influenced in any way as to its content. I have to simply take it as it appears. One of the themes that does emerge from Dr Hull's paper is that, while it is supportive of the work of bodies like UNFPA, it is supportive from the perspective, in the context of these human rights issues, that the work of foreign donors in China, far from legitimising abuses that may in fact occur there, helps counter those abuses, helps counter coercive practices, and promotes the principle of voluntary participation in family planning.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Where is the evidence for that?

—-That is a judgment that is made and the judgment is made on the basis that external presence of this kind provides first-hand observation of how programs work, provides opportunities for policy dialogue and provides opportunities for the kind of pressure to be imposed that is the only thing likely to produce results. Moreover, apart from that kind of dialogue and policy level communication, by providing technical advice and better contraception, there would appear to be little rational doubt that foreign assistance will also help reduce the number of abortions. After all, the UNFPA does provide three million improved, I am told, IUDs a year, which is estimated to result in 300,000 fewer unwanted pregnancies each year than might otherwise occur.

SPEECH.PARA: The other argument which underlies all this and which I think also appears in Dr Hull's paper--whether you agree with it or not, it is at least a credible prima facie argument--is the argument that defunding a Chinese family planning program would only result in more authoritarian practices, as cadres sought to achieve the same targets that are given but with fewer resources to do so.

These are matters we cannot debate in full on this occasion, any more than this environment has allowed us to debate these matters in full on any previous occasion. I simply ask Senator Harradine to accept a little more readily the good faith of those whose basic views about the appropriateness of population policies are different from his own, just as I can assure him that I and others in my Department, those in AIDAB and those who are involved in this process do accept his own good faith, his own integrity, and his own genuineness of commitment to the values and principles that he espouses.

By all means let us debate the policy. By all means let us debate the factual material, the objective material, that is made available. Let us debate whether conclusions follow from premises. Let us debate the causality, the effectiveness, of these different arguments. But do not, please, let us work from the premise that somehow there is an inherent bias and unprofessionalism, a lack of integrity or a lack of principle on the part of any of the people who are doing their best to wrestle with these very difficult issues.

On one final specific matter, Senator Harradine mentioned the position of Dr Hull and Dr Hull's wife, Dr Valerie Hull. I am advised that she has recently returned to AIDAB after a two-year leave of absence and that AIDAB is ensuring, with her active cooperation, that she is not in a position of authority over any population consultancy contracts which might involve Dr Terence Hull. That is an obvious precaution that has been taken of the kind that one would expect a professional outfit such as AIDAB to take. I hope that will lay to rest at least one of the fears that might exist about the Hull family's involvement in population policy matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I object to the Minister indicating to the Committee that I may not respect Dr Hull's integrity. It is not the point at all. He has been involved in a campaign of support for the United Nations Fund for Population Activities.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister says that he supports UNFPA. He is a politician. I suppose Dr Hull is entitled to support UNFPA. His Department gets money from UNFPA. He asked the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for more money for UNFPA and other population control organisations. He has done this over a number of years. Dr Hull's track record is there. If the Department wanted an objective analysis of human rights violations in China, why did it get a man with that track record of support for population control programs which by their very nature are coercive, though he personally opposes those coercive aspects? Nobody has denied that Nafis Sadik, the Executive-Director of UNFPA, praised the China population control program.

When I said that this document is political, I said it deliberately. This document was produced by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau, written by Dr Hull--AIDAB paid Dr Hull for it--as a response to what a member of the House of Representatives said in a speech. Critics of coercion in family planning, like Mr Bradford--
the member of parliament in the other place--

have called for the withdrawal of funds for national programs and from the international agencies which support national programs. The above discussion shows that this suggestion is simplistic and that there is no evidence that foreign funds or advice are the cause of coercion, except indirectly through the promotion of management techniques involving targets which provoke authoritarian bureaucratic systems to put pressure on clients to invoke compliance.

The program in Indonesia complained of by Mr Bradford was, in fact, the result of pressures put on the Indonesians by the United Nations Population Fund, by the World Bank and by the World Health Organisation. As authority for that I quote Dr Hull et al in an article entitled `Indonesia's Family Planning Story: Success and Challenge' which appeared in the Population Bulletin Volume 32, No. 6 of November 1977. In that article Dr Hull stated:
The turning point in government policy--
that is, Indonesian policy--

came with an invited mission of foreign experts in the fall of 1969, sponsored by the United Nations, the World Bank and the World Health Organisation. The mission judged family planning achievement to that time as disappointing, primarily because of inadequate organisation and administration. Later embodied in a first Five-Year Family Planning Program . . . their recommendations included . . . a doubling of the five-year target for new acceptors from three to six million. Organisationally, the mission advocated government involvement on a massive scale, from a Central Family Planning Institute with a chairman nominated by the President, down through provincial, regency and subdistrict institutes chaired by governors, regents and subdistrict heads.

There we have an admission that it is the pressure from these international organisations that is the problem. We certainly have a political document here, published by AIDAB, the bottom line of which recommends further funds for these international agencies which were the cause of the problem in the first place.

If that is not a political document, I do not know what is. All I say is that if the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is to adopt a principled approach and have these vital issues assessed and discerned professionally and objectively it ought to go to somebody who does not have a vested interest--I talk about vested interest in a polite sense--in these particular types of programs.

Mr Chairman, we are talking about taxpayers' money. As the Minister said, we can have debates on these issues at other times. However, I have looked at Recent Population Policy in China and it is also fatally flawed. In its appendices--I have just had a five-minute look at the paper--it proposed to include critiques of the book by John S. Aird, but only negative ones. Some highly respected Chinese scholars have praised Aird's book. The way that the paper happens to deal with my contributions is--I will not say `contemptible'--political. On these important matters of human rights I ask that the Department get someone who will be able to professionally discern the issues relating to human rights and go to the questions, the philosophical discussions, about human rights, not somebody who is following the party line.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I know by now that I will never get the last word in any of these discussions with Senator Harradine; so I do not want to prolong this debate unmercifully, except to say that I really do think the quality of these publications and these research documents should be looked at entirely on their own terms and not by reference to some perception as to the basic position of the person writing the articles. I turn now to the Ready Reserve. During the Estimate Committee hearings we asked a number of detailed questions about the Ready Reserve and particularly about costings. Although I do not intend to pursue this matter now, it remains a contentious issue which I do not think will be resolved until the figures are in.

Today I want to talk about what happens after the money has been spent; after the reservists have actually been trained. What guarantees do we have to ensure that they will stay and do what they have been trained and paid to do? The answer is simple: we have no guarantees. There is no legislation in place to ensure that trained and paid ready reservists will be required to render the specified service that the Government has set down for them in its new force structure. They do not have a return of service obligation. One wonders how this could have been introduced without the taxpayers' interests being protected.

It has always surprised me how easy it is for a government to spend other people's money without concern for what happens after it has been spent. This Government spends a great deal of money on paying for the final year of education, often an honours year, of promising university students who are brought into government departments as cadets after they have graduated. But there is no obligation on those who win this final year of government sponsorship and financial gain to take a cadetship in a government department. I have heard of some students who have never even been to Canberra and set foot in the department which sponsored them, although they retained all the payments and were given a Public Service number, associated benefits and accrued holiday leave.

It strikes me that the Ready Reserve incentives are in the same league--a lot of dollars are being thrown about with no guarantees. This worries me because I have heard that the majority of ready reservists already enlisted were unemployed before entry. I understand that this is the case with the majority of those who made formal applications. I wonder whether they will stay around after the recession lifts or whether they will go back into their chosen career options.

What worries me further is the sloppy approach by the Government and by senior military officers who claim that the ready reservists can serve overseas in peacekeeping activities such as those in Cambodia. Minister Bilney and General Gration have both said this publicly. Minister Bilney in his press release of 3 October said:

. . . by replacing two, understrength, under-equipped Regular battalions with three, fully manned and equipped Ready Reserve battalions--able to be deployed, including overseas on the same basis as Regulars.
The Mercury of 3 October states:
The Chief of the Defence Force, General Peter Gration, said Ready Reserve personnel would be equipped after 12 months of training to handle overseas deployment.
I believe that that is simply not true. At least, it will not be true unless an amendment is made to the Defence Act. I have been told that this is not necessary.

Call-out of the Army Reserve under the Defence Act is defined under sections 50E and 50F and it applies to the Ready Reserve as part of the Army Reserve. Section 50E defines call-out in a time of war or defence emergency and section 50F defines call-out in a time other than in a time of war or defence emergency. By this definition, peacekeeping would obviously fall under section 50F but, in both sections, call-out can occur only where the Governor-General considers it desirable to do so for the defence of Australia.

In the Act, the phrase `the defence of Australia' is not defined. However, it would be reasonable to assume that United Nations peacekeeping is not undertaken for the defence of Australia. Certainly, this would be open to challenge. An important point to remember is that Australian reservists who serve overseas in any capacity, as they did in the Gulf war and in peacekeeping in Namibia, are individual volunteers. They are not called up. The concept is one of Ready Reserve units replacing regular battalions, not individual reserves filling places in regular units.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have also said, if there is any difficulty about this, if the new Act is introduced by the autumn session next year--and even Senator Newman would concede this--it will well and truly cover the situation because the first ready reservists will complete their full year service in January the following year. We will have a look at that. We have already had a look at it, but there is no harm in re-checking. I will refer Senator Newman's view, as expressed today, to my Department's officers for evaluation. Again, as I have said, if it has to be remedied we will remedy it in the autumn session.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister, but does that mean to say that the compulsion which would be introduced by such legislation next year would be retrospective? The Defence Force is enlisting people from now on. Will they be enlisted under one set of circumstances and will the Government then introduce legislation that is binding on them retrospectively? Is that the way the Government would be looking at going?

—-I doubt whether people who join the Ready Reserve at the moment would be under any misapprehension as to what their potential future duties should be--Senator Newman has outlined them and I have outlined them.

—-On the question of legal obligation, I thought I read a statement--or reported statement--by the Minister, just before he brought down the force structure review, that he was going to get a legal opinion on this particular question. Did the Minister get it? If so, did it come from outside the Department? What is the position?
—-No. I indicated that I would seek advice on the matter, and that advice was sought within the Department.
—-But you have had no outside advice?

—-I will have to check that to see whether the advice provided to me was based on any outside legal opinion. I do not believe that it has been referred to the Attorney-General's office. I am advised that no external advice was sought.

—-Will the Minister indicate what will happen to people who change their minds after they have received some or all of the training and some or all of the money as ready reservists? How will the Government enforce it?

—-Although they are paid during their first year, the bonuses, et cetera, are paid at the end of the year of service and not during the year. If, for instance, people decide to go walkabout in the first three or six months, they will not be remunerated as they normally would if they served the full year.
—-Does the Minister not see any circumstances under which there would be a requirement to pay back money?

—-No, we have not contemplated that at this stage. One of the things we have put in is a review in three years time. The main reason for the review in three years time rather than two years, as some may have wanted, is to look at the retention rate over time. Each June we will be reporting back to Cabinet on that retention rate and how progress is going. Obviously, if a major problem occurred we would take the necessary remedial action. If people do not want to continue, do not enjoy the life, do not become part of the military ethos, frankly, we would probably not want them.
—-Is it correct that the Army has wanted some form of contractual arrangement with the reservists?

—-I am certainly not aware of that but I will have some inquiries made. I will give Senator Newman an answer if the Army has been looking at it, and if she receives no response from me she can assume that it is not so.
—-It is my understanding that it is so. Have officers given any attention to amending sections 38 and 39 of the Defence Act?
—-I have no information on that.

—-Is that because the Minister has no legal adviser with him? The Minister has some fairly senior officers of his Department here. The Ready Reserve is one of the issues listed for debate today and I would have thought that, therefore, he would have people here who would be able to answer a question like that.
—-By my inability to give Senator Newman a direct answer, the presumption is no, I do not have a such a person here at the moment.

—-It is my understanding that the Minister has given thought to amending those sections. Can the Minister indicate how long it will be before such amending legislation will be available to the Parliament? What will be the situation with regard to the Navy and the Air Force? I understand that their regulations are not even as sophisticated as the Army's.
—-Quite clearly, given my previous answer, I will take that on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister but it is not terribly satisfactory when we are trying to get to the bottom of the nation's legislative arrangements with the new ready reservists.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern is that there was a great flourish when, in May, I remind you, Mr Chairman, the Government's force structure review was introduced. It heavily relied on replacing regular units with Ready Reserve units. We have the Ready Reserve trumpeted around the country by this Government as being the solution to Australia's defence and then we find, many months down the track--five months or something like it--that no information is available to the Parliament on how the obligations of these people will be honoured.

I find it quite unsatisfactory that the Minister can come in here and cannot tell us precisely what he is going to do. One would have expected that that would be decided before the Ready Reserve concept was announced. It is not only a question of the legislative arrangements; it is also a question of the employer incentives. Clearly, they were not determined and appear to be still not finalised.

It is unsatisfactory to have an ad hoc defence force being organised as it goes. It does not lead to any confidence as to the sort of force the Government is going to produce, let alone its ability to defend the country. If this is any indication of the way Defence and the Government have been organising to have Australia defended, I find it totally unsatisfactory. It is but perhaps a symptom, but it is a symptom that gives me great concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is not my job to knock down all the straw men that Senator Newman sets up. When she says we have gone around the country trumpeting the Ready Reserve as the answer to all our defence problems, that is simply not true; it is a total exaggeration of the Government's position. The Ready Reserve is part of the Australian Defence Force strategy. It is not the dominant part and never has been; nor was it the dominant part of the force structure review. I am not going to respond to some of the exaggerations Senator Newman put in that contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister for his contribution, but only this week his colleague the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) was telling a seminar in Melbourne that this was the way that the Government was going to improve our defence effort.
—-The way or one of the ways?

—-The way. I wrote it down but I do not have it with me now. I can assure the Minister that I am not being unkind to Mr Bilney in what he said. The Government has tried to take comfort in the proposal of the Ready Reserve and, when we come here and find that we cannot get very much detail months after it has been announced, it is pretty unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: I have one more issue to raise relating to the ready reservists and legislation. How will the Government protect ready reservists who may suffer from discrimination either in getting a job or in keeping a job because of their Ready Reserve requirements?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I doubt that people would be discriminated against in this sense, any more than any reservist could be discriminated against, but it is a two-way street. Having done the year's training, many of the ready reservists will be a more attractive employment proposition even though the employer will have to release them for two two-week blocks. That is, by sticking out a year's training, by--probably, in many cases, for the first time in their lives--getting into a routine, they will absorb some of the qualities that employers look towards.

SPEECH.PARA: That was certainly my impression when talking to some of the employers who came to the one launch, at least, that I was involved in. They found that the recruiting in that particular area is very attractive. It is hard to estimate, other than by an intuitive feeling, as to where the ready reservists will be drawn from. I notice that Senator Newman said she thought they would be all the unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Not all.

—-No, not all. But it would be attractive to some of those people. The honourable senator was worried about whether that was the dominant influence in our thinking. We have already received 7,000 inquiries about the Ready Reserve.
—-But there are nearly one million unemployed as well.

—-I said that we have had 7,000 inquiries, which will give us rather a broad scope of people to choose from. It is a scheme which is more attractive to some applicants than it is to others. It is not simply attractive to the unemployed; it is very attractive to some university and tertiary students, farmers, et cetera. A large percentage of people--although maybe not much more than a majority--will be able to give their return of service without having to involve an employer.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it would be quite difficult to legislate to protect against discrimination in employment. Nevertheless, I am happy to look at it. I think it would be quite difficult to put in legislation criteria that covered why a person was rejected for a job. It would be difficult to prove why they were rejected. It has been tried in other areas, as the honourable senator would know--especially in affirmative action programs and in many other contexts. It is not an easy thing to do. If it does evolve as a problem, any government would have to tackle it; but, first, I would like to see whether it will be a problem.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand the Minister's hesitancy about this matter, but just because it is hard to prove sex discrimination or racial discrimination does not mean to say that we do not have it on the books as a way of saying, `This is what we believe must not happen'. It is a way for governments to say, `This is a priority for us; this is the way we are leading this country. We do not believe in sex discrimination and we do not believe in racial discrimination'. I would say that we also believe in supporting those people who are prepared to defend this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I can well envisage occasions when two equally well qualified people may be queuing for a job, particularly in difficult economic times, and an employer finds out that there is an obligation not only to give somebody his or her four weeks annual leave but also to give that person 50 days to serve the country. No doubt, that will not be given as the reason for not employing that person, but that person's chances of getting that job will be jeopardised. I think it will be necessary to say that this is something which the country thinks is important enough to support. I understand that it may be difficult to prove, but that does not mean to say that it is not necessarily a desirable objective.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-A slight difference I would draw, without disagreeing with much of what the honourable senator has said, is that we know from our experience that there has been a fair degree of discrimination on the basis of gender and race and, particularly these days, discrimination on the basis of age. I am sure the honourable senator has constituents in the age group of 45 to 55 years who are eminently employable, but all of the job advertisements ask for a younger person or the excuse is given that they are over-qualified for the job.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator has alerted us to a potential problem. We do not know yet whether it will emerge, although we know the other problems have emerged. If it does emerge, the Government may take remedial action. It will be difficult action to take, but I am not saying that we will not take it. But I stress that when two 20-year-olds walk into an employer's office it may be that on many occasions the person who has been through a year's full time military training will get the job over and above the other person because the employer knows that person has had to show a regular form of discipline. I am not talking about Colonel Blimp-type discipline here; I am talking about the sorts of things that the armed forces demand and get. It is no surprise to me that, after a year's training, people come out with all sorts of different social and organisational skills which enable them to organise their own lives. Quite frankly, that puts them well in advance of many of their competitors.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I agree with the Minister, and I have no doubt, that those people would be very much better employees for having spent a year with the defence forces. But I do not believe that will necessarily be the view of employers who perhaps do not know, as the Minister and I know, what the Defence Force could achieve in a year of professional training of a young person. I am concerned that people may in fact face that discrimination. The Minister has said today that, if such a situation does arise, the Government will then look at legislating to protect ready reservists. That in itself may be sufficient to send out the message that we as a country intend to support these people and that they will not be disadvantaged.

—-I am interested in the specific case which the honourable senator has raised. But, in the more general case, when a new scheme is introduced I will not fight every demon at once; I will wait and, if problems do emerge, I will deal with them promptly. Unfortunately, the legislative processes of government and of this chamber do not always assist in that regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At this point it might be convenient for me to ask a question about the Air Force Ready Reserve, arising from an answer which I received to a question on notice which is not listed on this sheet: there is no reason why it should be because it is a general reservation. Page 28 of the force structure review deals with the strategic strike force. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Specific proposals to maintain a strategic strike capability are:
a. Acquire small stocks of stand-off weapons for the F-111C.
b. For the first time, use twelve reserve F-111C crews to supplement the number of regular crews in the event of contingencies (and reduce the number of regular crews by three).

I think the figure for reductions in air regular crews has been taken into account. I do not know what the exact figure is, but that does not matter. During the Estimates process, I asked a question--No. 164--to the effect, `Can you provide me with a breakdown of the training you plan to provide Ready Reserve pilots for the strike reconnaissance force?'. I received an answer which stated that there are no plans to include air crews in the RAAF Ready Reserve element. Therefore, technically, the answer is none. The answer continued that a program was being implemented which would provide training for selected ex-regular F111 air crew who are members of the general Reserve, as I understand it, involving two days training once a year. I am concerned that there seems to be a major discrepancy between what is said in the force structure review and what has been said in the answer to me. Perhaps the Minister can clear this up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand that a small change may have been made in the process following the force structure review. The reserves which the RAAF intends to use are general reserves, not ready reserves. They will be in the general Air Force Reserve, not in the Ready Reserve. I am not sure whether there was a change of emphasis between the time when the force structure review was put down and when the question was answered. I think that resolves the apparent contradiction which you see.

SPEECH.PARA: CHAIRMAN--We move to program 1--`Forces Executive'. Senator Newman has three reservations in that area. Are there any questions?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I refer to the M113 project. During the Estimates Committee hearings Vice-Admiral Beaumont stated that ground mobility for the Army was a high priority and had been for some time. I disputed that. I said that the high priority must have been given only recently because I had asked about it for some years and had been given the impression that it was on the back burner. I have since looked back at previous Estimates Hansards and seen that my observations were correct. In the Additional Estimates of 1989, when speaking about defence development I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Am I to assume the M113 project is dead?
Dr Brabin-Smith answered:
No. I would not assume that.
I asked:
Do I assume it is still on the back-burner?
Dr Brabin-Smith answered:
I suppose it is fair to say it is not on the front-burner, yes.

In the Budget Estimates of October 1988 I asked about ground mobility priority. No-one said then that it had any priority. It has not always been a priority, as Vice-Admiral Beaumont would have us believe. I said:

I would ask about the mobile ground forces, if that is a priority capability area how mobile are they going to be if we are not prepared to do something about the M113s? Have we taken a decision about that?
Vice-Admiral Knox answered:
. . . a decision has not yet been made on the upgrading of the M113 vehicles.
Further, in Budget Estimates in October 1987 I asked about the status of the M113s. Mr Ives said:
As I understand it study is going on as to what we will do next.
I then asked whether that meant it had slipped. I was told by General Francis:
It depends how you define slippage, it will probably be approved later than we originally intended.
I then asked when it was originally hoped it would start. General Francis said:
I have forgotten. It would have been in the Budget just presented.

That went on. Answers such as those that I have just quoted give no indication of priority. If ground mobility was a priority issue, answers such as `I have forgotten' and `study is going on as to what we will do next' just do not fit in. In fact, we get the impression that it was being stalled, especially when Dr Brabin-Smith said that there was:
. . . no delay due to lack of money in the implementation of the modernisation of the M113s . . .
If the delay was not a question of money, was it delayed because it was not a priority issue?

If ground mobility has not had priority, despite Vice-Admiral Beaumont's claims that it has, why has it not had priority, given that its priority in the White Paper seems pretty clear. The White Paper stated under the heading `Australia's defence strategy':

Defence in depth gives priority to the ability of the ADF to mount operations of defeating the enemy forces in our area of direct military interest. This means that we must have forces capable of tracking and targeting the adversary . . . having a comprehensive range of defensive capabilities including air defence, mine countermeasures and protection of coastal trade--and embodying mobile land forces able to defeat hostile incursions at remote locations.
The White Paper further states:
Within this planning framework, priority capability areas include--
after surveillance, maritime forces, mine countermeasures, ground reconnaissance and surveillance--
mobile ground forces able to defeat hostile incursions at remote localities and protect military and infrastructure assets that support the projection of our maritime power.

Although it was clearly stated in 1987 in the White Paper that that was something we had to be able to achieve, never in successive Estimates committee hearings has the mobility of ground forces had any sense of urgency or priority. I was astounded when I was told in the Estimates Committee hearings that, somehow, this was a matter of high priority. It clearly is not; it clearly has not been. There has been no sense of urgency about the M113 upgrade.

We are going off on a frolic occasioned by the Minister Beazley when, instead of borrowing one of the Canadian light armoured vehicles for the Kangaroo 89 exercise, he suddenly had a rush of blood to the head and there was some June money left in the Budget and he bought 15. That is another matter which will be taken up by my colleagues Senator Durack and Senator MacGibbon.

We cannot allow the LAV procurement to distract us from the basic need to upgrade the M113s. The fact is that the Senate Estimates Committee has, over several years now, been given the clear impression that this has not been given the priority that it should have in the Department of Defence and that the Government obviously does not see any need to implement statements made quite clearly in its White Paper. What are we going to do about ground mobility for the defence forces? Are we going to rely entirely on the LAVs or are we going to do something about the M113s? When did the M113 project get the priority that Vice-Admiral Beaumont claimed it had during the Estimates Committee hearings? Just what is the reality of that priority? What is happening to the M113s?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It would be wrong, of course, to assert that Army mobility and the M113 are synonymous, and only by themselves. Mobility, in that sense, has been affected enormously by the Black Hawk program, by the hundreds of trucks and the Mack program. I think there are something like 1,800 Unimog trucks. I saw the 1,800th roll out last year. There are the Perentie vehicles, the Land Rovers and there will be the LAV 25s. I do not think Senator Newman meant to assert that Army mobility is simply a matter of the M113 vehicle.

SPEECH.PARA: In response to her question No. 6, we have indicated that there will be an upgrade of those vehicles between 1994 and 1998, at a cost of about $40m. If Senator Newman is asking me to adjudicate past bouts at Estimates committees going back to 1987, I have not read that material so I am not in a position to comment on it. I am more concerned with the present and future than with the past although I agree that the past has some relevance to planning. There is a major degree of emphasis in the Army now on its mobility and the lessons that have been learnt from various exercises.

As I said, I would not restrict a view of Army mobility just to the tracking vehicles. There are numerous other vehicles that have been purchased. I had a ride in one of the new tank carriers the other day. They were very impressive acquisitions in terms of Army mobility. Finally, Senator Newman asked when we could move onto the tracking vehicles program and the answer is 1994 to 1998 for the upgrade at a cost of $40m.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask the Minister whether that is set in concrete. Is there a firm planning date? Has it been approved by the Minister? Has it been approved by Cabinet? How firm is it? We have had those sorts of semi-assurances, if you like, for some time now. I am not really all that impressed with things that are down the track. I want to know exactly what its status is.

—-We have to be impressed with things down the track in defence. It is not a day to day matter. The best description at the moment is `semi-firm'. We have not called for or requested interest in this, called tenders or anything else. I assume that it has pink book status at the moment. One of the things I have been trying to do, in the force structure review, is to free up as much funding so those pink book projects can be realised. It has that status. As we move nearer to 1994 the position will firm up.
—-What does the Minister mean by `firming up'?

—-Like any other pink book project, it is there as an aspiration. We have the definition now of the sort of mobility that we want; we have the realisation in terms of funds. A better option is to upgrade these vehicles rather than replace them. That is our expectation of what may occur. I am not going to give an absolute categorical guarantee that that will occur if other priorities overtake. That is unlikely at this stage. This is a project that Army is most interested in. I think it will fit its priorities. I cannot give an absolute guarantee. I will not do that on any project through to the year 2000.
—-I do not want to labour the point, but the Minister did say that it is an aspiration.
—-My definition of `aspiration' and Senator Newman's are probably different. I went on to define what I meant by the word.
—-It still sounded very much like a wish list rather than a fact.

—-It is well beyond a wish list, but I will not give an absolute guarantee in respect of a future project starting in 1994. I cannot bind the next Labor government or an incoming conservative government to that.
—-We move to program 2, which deals with logistic support for the Navy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to ask some further questions on the Oberon submarine refit. I say by way of introduction that on 6 August a question on notice was asked by Senator Alston and the Minister replied to it on 10 September. The question was:

SPEECH.PARA: During 1990-1, what was the total Commonwealth funding provided to each of the bodies listed in the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration's report List of Commonwealth Bodies, June 1991, as within your portfolio.

On the second page there was a list of statutory offices, non-statutory bodies and principal companies. In the principal companies there was an entry for Australian Defence Industries, which I presume would be the Garden Island crowd, for $29,545,000. Can you give me a general idea of what that attribution was for?

TALK.START.PARA: —-We will have to chase that up. We pay a lot more than that to ADI, as Senator MacGibbon will realise. Whether it is a payment for one particular section of a project or an amalgam of different projects, I am not sure.

—-I was referring to question No.1120 among the questions on notice. There is no way of working out what that payment was for. Moving on to the Garden Island dockyard, does the Department have any estimate of labour costs per hour, or in any meaningful way for services produced at Garden Island?

—-I am sure that an estimate could be obtained. Garden Island is now run by ADI. We would have to seek information from ADI. I am not sure what Senator MacGibbon wants. Does he want an average per worker cost per hour?

—-I realise that it is difficult because of the range of skills involved. I would like a comparative figure of costings for Garden Island in respect of contracts undertaken for the Navy. Has HMAS Otway entered Garden Island for a mid-cycle docking? If so, what is the contract time and what is the contract figure?
—-It is a mid-cycle docking. It comes out in mid-November.
—-Is there a cost for the docking service available?
—-We do not have that figure, but we can obtain it for you. All we know is that the project is on time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Evidence was given to the Committee that HMAS Onslow came out of service in November 1989 and the refit started in February 1991, which is a period, depending on how one counts it, of between 14 and 16 months that the ship was out of service before the refit started. Evidence was also given that Otama came out in September 1990 and it is estimated that its refit will start in February 1992, which again, depending on how one counts, is a period of 16 to 18 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Because during that considerable block of time the Commonwealth has not had the use of that asset, is there any contractual liability on the dockyard for the loss of service of that asset, or do we just accept the fact that there has been three years lack of use by the Commonwealth of equipment worth possibly $100m?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think two issues are involved. The first relates to the time the submarine spent in the dockyard. It is expected to turn around a vessel in 85 to 90 weeks in general. If they were to delay that process while the ship was in dock, it would be to their disadvantage, not ours. The delay in putting the ships into dock was caused by a multitude of reasons, some of which were crewing reasons. Some may have been due to the fact that I wanted to put that particular contract under scrutiny, which I did when I became Minister. The changeover in Ministers would have had some effect. I understand that there are some crewing reasons for that sort of timing, and we are undermanned in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: It has to be broken up into two sections. As to the time the vessel spends in dock, everyone said that the last submarine to come out of Cockatoo would be late, but it was not. If Garden Island cannot deliver within the specified time, in what is regarded as a reasonable time, it will cost it rather than the Government, as I understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand that the Commonwealth must bear the loss of service while the ship is under dockyard refit. But my question relates to the period of roughly 14 months before the submarines, both the Otama and Onslow, entered the dockyard. In so far as one imposes a penalty on the dockyard for exceeding the contract overhaul or refit time, I would argue that there is therefore an economic penalty also through the loss of service to the Navy in not having use of those two submarines when they were lying tied up to the wharf for a period of about 14 months before they entered the dockyard. I am asking whether the Commonwealth will recover from the dockyard for that period of inactivity, or whether that is accepted as a Navy responsibility.

—-It is not the dockyard's fault in that case. If one wanted to project an argument that there has been a waste of an asset, we have to cop the blame for that. But there are a multitude of reasons, some resolvable and some not resolvable, for that delay. We did not enter into a contract only to be told that we had to wait another six months before we could put the ship into the dock. That simply did not occur in this process. If there were delays and if it is argued that that is an underutilisation of an asset, the Navy and the Government will have to wear that.

—-Would it be possible to plan the letting of contracts so that in future the Navy does not lose somewhere near 14 months in the operation of a vessel before it goes in for refit? Given the finite life of these platforms, it does not seem to make sense to have them out of service for big blocks of time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would certainly concede that it would be better to be able to structure them in such a way. One thing we have had to resolve with the closing of Cockatoo is that we did not have the same continuity when we went to a new bidder. It often depends on whether the contract is for one submarine or several submarines.

SPEECH.PARA: The question concerning the current class of Oberons is virtually resolved. The two we have mentioned here today are going through and then that is it. When the Government and the Navy get to the Collins class, there will be a need for very stringent programming into the future. There will be a very strong argument to have one contractor so that we can plan into the future to make sure that maximum use is made of assets. That will be very important. It could be complicated if we go for the Sterling engines down the track. Nevertheless, the sort of philosophy that Senator MacGibbon is putting forward in terms of timing is a good one. The Government should try to meet that sort of timing.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Since Onslow went into refit in February 1991, I presume that some progress payments have been made. Could the Minister advise the Senate when, what for and for what amount those progress payments have been made to the GDI?
—-I am sure that we will not be able to give Senator MacGibbon the exact details at this stage. I do not know whether we have a ballpark figure. Approximately $21m has been paid so far.
—-What requests beyond the normal have been made for new equipment as a result of the dismantling and inspection of Onslow on this refit?

—-I am informed that at this stage we do not know of anything special. I am not sure whether they are at the stage where they can fully define emergent work as they have discovered and defined it. I will leave the answer at that--that there is nothing at the moment. However, I will ask for that to be double-checked. If something is new or substantial, I will have Senator MacGibbon informed.
—-Would the Minister ask whether any new propeller shafts have been requested by GDI for the ship?
—-Is Senator MacGibbon talking about new propeller shafts or simply replacement ones?
—-Replacement ones.

—-That is where we could easily get into a misunderstanding over the term `new equipment'. If we use the term `replacement', we certainly will not get confused. I will get the information for Senator MacGibbon.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to ask a couple of questions in relation to the Oberon refit and the Otama refit. We certainly spent a lot of time on this in the Estimates Committee hearing, so I do not want to prolong it now. An answer to a question on notice that I asked mentioned alternative strategies that ADI was looking at to speed up its ability to begin refitting the Otama. Senator Ray will recall at the Estimates Committee that concern was expressed about the delay in completing the refit of the Onslow for various reasons and that that would impact on the time when the refit of the Otama would commence.

SPEECH.PARA: It may have been said in the Estimates committee hearings answers or in response to a question on notice that ADI was looking at some means of speeding this up. Perhaps the Minister's departmental officers are looking at ways in which it could be speeded up. I wonder whether the Minister could provide me with any information about what these are and how successful they are likely to be or perhaps have already become.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not have any specific information on that. I know that ADI has entered into discussions with other people. Whether they have reached fruition, or are ever likely to, I do not know. QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: New South Wales Industrial Relations Legislation

TALK.START.PARA: —-Has the Minister for Industrial Relations seen press reports noting the concerns expressed by members--nine judges--of the New South Wales Industrial Commission over their independence and status and the rights of citizens under the New South Wales Government's Industrial Relations Bill? Given the determination of the New South Wales Government to push the Bill through--a Bill which has been greeted by strident criticism from virtually all quarters--what implications are there for the Federal industrial relations system and the linkage between the two systems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yes, I have seen concerns by judges of the New South Wales Industrial Commission reported in at least two newspapers, and I quote from the report in front of me:

ANSWER.PARA: Angry judges from the New South Wales Industrial Commission are threatening to quit because of changes to their roles proposed by the Government's Industrial Relations Bill. Judges fear their judicial independence would be compromised by the Bill.
The report says further:

The dissatisfied judges say changes to the system will defy constitutional convention. They say `they are not out to. . . sabotage the system but want a guarantee from the Government to discuss a workable arrangement'.

In these reports as well, Mr Barry O'Keefe, the President of the New South Wales Bar Association, queries the constitutional base upon which the New South Wales legislation is based. He argues that it has serious constitutional consequences for the independence of the judiciary and for the protection of citizens' rights in the courts. It is also reported that the New South Wales Industrial Relations Minister, John Fahey, wrote to the Commission President, Mr Bill Fisher, saying that amendments proposed by judges to the Bill were unacceptable.
It is not just the judges in New South Wales who are concerned about the New South Wales Industrial Relations Bill. I quote Mr Geoff Huard, the Anglican Archdeacon of Sydney:
We must guard against the pendulum swinging too far. To allow this Bill free passage would be simply to swap one set of work problems for another.
I quote William Patterson, the executive director of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation, an employer body:
Threats of heavy fines against employers and unions, voluntary union membership and enterprise agreements are theoretical exercises which I see as creating, not settling, industrial disputes.
The Reverend Harry Herbert of the Uniting Church says:
The New South Wales industrial relations Bill is likely to produce an upsurge in the exploitation of workers.
The Catholics for Justice and Peace say:
The proposed legislation further disadvantages workers. We urge you to withdraw this unjust legislation.
The leader of the New South Wales Democrats, Elisabeth Kirkby, says:
The wages and conditions of workers in low paid, low status jobs would be devastated.
An Independent, Mr John Hatton, says:
My grandchildren and their grandchildren will suffer third world working conditions.
Doug Wright, the New South Wales executive director of the Metal Trades Industry Association, an employer body, says:
The Bill will give unscrupulous employers an opportunity to exploit workers in a recessed economy.

They are the concerns of judges echoed by the churches, by employers and by politicians. Certainly, one knows from the record that unions are strongly opposed to this legislation. I am concerned that this is an attempt to import into Australia the industrial regulation that applies in New Zealand, exploitative legislation that it be. I am concerned as well that the strike figures for the Australian national performance will now be worsened because of the Greiner Government's inability to manage sensible industrial relations.

I am concerned that this Bill is seriously flawed and it should be withdrawn. It uses phrases like `enterprise bargaining' to cloak an ideological agenda. The effect on the Federal industrial relations system is hard to gauge at this stage, although I have been pursuing a program of voluntary integration of the State and Federal commissions. As a consequence of that program I have elevated the President of the New South Wales Industrial Commission, His Honour Mr Justice Bill Fisher, QC, to a Deputy President of the Federal Commission. I do not think it is appropriate to comment on the effect that that might have at this stage when it is merely a Bill because it is appropriate, only when it becomes law, for me to comment on what the impact on the Federal Commission might be. Suffice it for me to say in these circumstances, though, that I hope commonsense prevails, that the overwhelming voice of the community is heard by the New South Wales Government, that the Government takes off its ideological blinkers and sees the wider issues and that the Government pulls this Bill out.

—-I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Can the Minister help allay the concerns of many Australian women regarding silicone breast implants, particularly given Monday night's Four Corners program on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Concerns about silicone breast implants, as portrayed on the Four Corners program on Monday night, have also found a similar voice in Canada and the United States. This has prompted action by the various governments to obtain advice from the manufacturers to justify the quality and safety of these devices. The Therapeutic Goods Administration wrote to all manufacturers of breast implants in July seeking such justification by 30 November this year. Since almost all breast implants are imported from the United States, this action is being taken in conjunction and cooperation with the United States Food and Drug Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: As in the United States, it is likely that some companies will withdraw their products from the market or be required to withdraw through failure to submit information. The polyurethane coated implant which was the subject of much concern in the Four Corners program was withdrawn from Australia and worldwide by the company in April. In Australia we have presently exempted saline filled prostheses from this review of safety and quality and we will be pushing manufacturers to use water based fillings.

It is the responsibility of the medical profession to ensure that patients are fully informed about the risks associated with breast implants. The ABC program The Investigators on Tuesday, 8 October highlighted the Government's therapeutic device problem reporting scheme, established to provide an avenue to alert regulatory authorities about problems that patients experience with medical devices. Patients who experience a problem with such medical devices can call in on a hotline in respect of their concern.

The Government is committed to increasing the role of women in the therapeutic devices area--a crucial area of women's health. To this end, over the past 12 months, the Minister has increased the representation of women members on the Therapeutic Device Evaluation Committee from one to four. I believe that should ameliorate some of the concerns of women in Australia.
