—-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Do doctors who bulkbill order more pathology than those who do not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Most medical practitioners do bulkbill to some extent and, therefore, it is very difficult to put together an answer.
—-Oh, come on!

—-Senator Herron should know that, apart from some country doctors, almost all practices bulkbill their pensioners, so it is very difficult to make the clear distinctions which lay at the base of Senator Herron's question.

ANSWER.PARA: I have some material which may be of assistance in relation to pathology services. For example, in paper No. 6, Directions for Pathology, of the health strategy, chapter 2 examined the rate of utilisation of pathology services by the extent to which the services were direct billed by the pathologist. That analysis showed that in 1988-89, 55.6 per cent of pathology services were direct billed. The proportion was lower for patients with four pathology services or less and for those with the highest use of over 24 services a year on average. Between these extremes, direct billing varied from 56 per cent to 61.3 per cent of services. However, there was no relationship between the volume of services ordered per patient and the proportion of services which were direct billed.

The health strategy paper on pathology also showed that there was very little difference in the number of pathology episodes per patient; the number of pathology services per episode; and the number of pathology services per patient between patients who were direct billed for all pathology services and those patients billed for all pathology services. In addition, national health strategy background paper No. 5, entitled The Effects of Consumer Co-Payments in Medical Care, examined direct billing. That analysis suggests that there are not quantitatively large differences in the use of services per patient attributable to direct billing.

The greatest difficulty in trying to answer Senator Herron's question is the fact that most medical practitioners direct bill to some extent. Therefore, it is impossible to make the very clear distinctions that are the premise to his question.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the evidence given in the New South Wales Royal Commission--
—-Gyles.

—-The Gyles Royal Commission. In the evidence, as reported in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald, multimillion dollar building fraud against the Federal Government is alleged. I further refer to the Minister's own assertions to this Parliament on a number of occasions that a careful eye is kept on tendering. I ask the Minister: how long has he been aware of the alleged fraud? Does he have any indication of how long this practice has been going on? Is he looking at his own Department for any negligence in not detecting this fraud?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Panizza does raise an issue which is of concern and that concern is obviously reflected by the article in yesterday's newspaper to which he referred. The Gyles Royal Commission has not as yet completed its final hearings on the reference relating to tendering matters. However, my Department has been in liaison with the Commission and, through a departmental officer and through other avenues, has been keeping a watching brief in respect of that particular hearing.

ANSWER.PARA: On 7 June, during previous hearings on this reference, the Royal Commission advised the Australian Construction Services that evidence concerning collusive tendering practices on several Commonwealth projects would, in fact, be heard. We were advised that they would be heard the following week. We then briefed counsel and counsel was granted leave to appear.

What has emerged in evidence during the Commission's hearings is that collusive practices had been widespread in private projects and, of course, in State and Commonwealth public works projects. The practice, I am advised, as has been indicated by the evidence, has been occurring for a long time. According to one witness it may have been going on for something like 35 years. The evidence also, I am advised, indicates that the practices are probably Australia-wide and have been effectively concealed from government and private clients.

In terms of the practices that we are talking about, there are probably four categories: firstly, agreements to pay fees to unsuccessful tenderers and to conceal those payments by the issue of false invoices; secondly, agreements to pay special fees to the Master Builders Association and/or the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors; thirdly, agreements that both parties would add the same amounts to their tenders to allow for the two preceding areas of costs; and, fourthly, various other collusive practices.

This information is not new. It has been before the Commission and I think it was canvassed by the media some four to six weeks ago, if not further back than that. The evidence does lead to concern on our level that there may have been breaches of several Commonwealth laws. I think Senator Panizza would understand that since these matters are under investigation by not only relevant Commonwealth agencies, but also by the Commission, then it is not appropriate for me to make any further comment at this time.

In terms of preventive measures, however, the New South Wales Government has instituted a requirement for tenderers and contractors to provide statutory declarations on these matters. I am informed that these have had some measure of success in this respect, although the sanctions available to the Commonwealth for non-compliance--if we were to do the same thing--are not as powerful. I have decided that suitable declarations will be requested from tenderers for all Commonwealth public work projects over $2m. I will be requesting that government business enterprises adopt the same tendering practice.

In respect of my Department, we have seconded a senior officer to assist in these matters over and above the person we have briefed. Mr Tim Robinson briefed his counsel to appear before the Commission. We have seconded a senior officer to assist in these matters and to provide liaison with the various agencies including the proposed building and construction industry reform agency.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Have you checked who was responsible in your Department?

—-I should add that at a recent meeting of State Ministers and me, that particular person was also offered and accepted as the link between us and State governments on matters relating to the collusive practices that Senator Panizza mentioned.

—-My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, concerns Cambodian refugees in Thailand. Is the Minister aware of reports that the Khmer Rouge is preparing to force displaced Cambodians from UN assisted camps in Thailand across the border into Khmer Rouge territory? How accurate are these claims? What is the Government's view on this reported enforced repatriation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am aware of reports along the lines that Senator Beahan refers to--that the Khmer Rouge has, among other things, replaced the elected administration of the Cambodian refugee camp at site eight in south-east Thailand and appears to be preparing for the forcible repatriation of the camp's inhabitants across the border into Khmer Rouge controlled Cambodian territory. The senior camp administrators, who are themselves members of the Khmer Rouge, were summoned to a Khmer Rouge military camp inside Cambodia on 4 October and they have not yet returned. They have been replaced by four new Khmer Rouge appointees.

ANSWER.PARA: The site eight camp is, of course, a Khmer Rouge controlled camp under the United Nations Border Relief Organisation. The Australian Government can only express its most serious concern at this development. The camp administrators were popularly elected, albeit under Khmer Rouge auspices, and there must be some real fears for their personal safety across the border. I hope that the Thai authorities will act to prevent any forcible repatriation of Cambodians from this camp.

The comprehensive settlement of the Cambodian problem, which does provide for an orderly repatriation program to be led and coordinated by the UNHCR, will be finalised in Paris next week. Annex 4 of that settlement clearly states:

Repatriation of Cambodian refugees and displaced persons should be voluntary and their decision should be taken in full possession of the facts. Choice of destination within Cambodia should be that of the individual. The unity of the family must be preserved.

On the eve of the signature of that international settlement, the international community must insist that the Khmer Rouge and, indeed, all parties to the forthcoming settlement act fully in accordance with arrangements laid down by the UN peace plan. In this context, I note that Prince Sihanouk has appealed to the resistance parties not to undertake unilateral repatriation of this kind.

Let me say finally that while these developments at site eight are certainly matters for concern and justify statements of the kind that I have just made, in no sense do they undermine the credibility of the comprehensive settlement which has now been agreed. The negotiation of that settlement has been a remarkable achievement and, certainly, a signature next week would be a very big milestone. But we have known all along that its implementation will be an extremely difficult and complex task, not least in this area of repatriation of displaced Cambodians. It is very important that the international community continues to focus very closely and very carefully on the implementation phase as well as the negotiation for settlement itself.

—-Senator Baume is a bit player in this little operation. He comes in out of the cold with no knowledge at all. Senator Parer has asked a whole range of questions relating to government consumption and government buildings in the past. He has had information given to him.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —-The sycophants from yesterday want to raise their voices today to make up for the crawling they did in their party room yesterday. If we can get the information for Senator Parer, we will do so.

—-My question, which refers to the question I asked on Monday and the answer that the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services gave on Monday evening, is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. The answer refers to estimates of the numbers of cardholders and non-cardholders having been part of the decision-making process. Can he table those estimates and the explanatory methodology? Naturally, I do not expect the Minister to have all of this information here, so I ask him whether he will he table it before the Senate rises at the end of this week.

—-I think an answer to the final question can be provided probably fairly readily. The question about the provision of quarterly statistics can also be answered fairly readily. But in respect of the question about the estimated number of cardholders and non-cardholders and the explanatory methodology, I would caution that this material may have been provided to the Cabinet for Cabinet deliberations, in which case there may be a constraint on making it available. —-My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I do not need to remind the Minister of either the very satisfactory inaugural flight from Australia to Taiwan or the fact that the first flight from Taiwan is due to touch down in Australia tomorrow. However, I do need to ask the Minister the following: first, does he acknowledge that Taiwan is now Australia's seventh largest trading partner? Secondly, is he aware that Thursday's flight will be catering specifically for journalists, travel agents and businessmen coming to extend both goodwill and business opportunities between our two countries? Thirdly, is he aware that the New Zealand Government, in recognising the realities of the situation, has abolished the requirement of an immigration visitors disclaimer, which the Australian press described last week as `grossly insulting'. Finally, has the Minister, in full recognition of the realities of the position and particularly considering that the first flight is due tomorrow, determined to remove this most ungracious and unnecessary disclaimer and warmly welcome our new visitors from Taiwan? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Taiwan is a very important trading partner of Australia and I am very happy indeed that, after some considerable period of protracted negotiations, the inaugural flights have now taken place or are in the process of taking place. I am well aware of how the negotiation in New Zealand was conducted on this particular matter. I am well aware of the basis and the principles on which we conducted the negotiation. I made absolutely clear that we were not going to be dragged successively into linking unrelated matters to the conditions under which the negotiation of the flight would occur. That is the position we maintained. The repeated tactic of linking mutually beneficial air services to essentially minor political issues was tiresome and somewhat counterproductive and we have responded accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: The matter of the visa disclaimer is something that I have already said justifies review. The one China policy we have is so well understood on both sides of the Taiwan straits now that there may well be a case for no longer retaining that. The matter is under review. I will conclude that review in a reasonably short period of time but I am in no particular rush to do so. That fact has been communicated to the Taiwanese negotiators. I know that they know the circumstances of our reaction and I will bear with such fortitude as I can command the indignation of the honourable senator or anybody else on this particular subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I ask Senator Evans a supplementary question. I appreciate the time and trouble that Senator Evans has taken in preparing such a full answer. But I would like the Minister to advise me on this: when he says `in the very short term future', does he mean by tomorrow or does he mean that it will not be by tomorrow; does he mean by this year or does he mean that it will not be by this year?
—-The matter is under review and I will deal with it when I regard it as appropriate to do so when the review is completed.

—-My question is also directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given Australia's deservedly high international reputation for its comprehensive cross-party opposition to the death penalty and its significant role in the adoption by the United Nations of the second optional protocol on the death penalty, I ask: first, in recent discussions with Prime Minister Namaliu, was the question of the tragic decision to reintroduce the death penalty in Papua New Guinea raised and, if so, what was the outcome of those discussions? Secondly, will the matter of the use of the death penalty in the United States be raised with US President Bush when he visits Australia later this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government's opposition to capital punishment is consistent and universal. The position is based on our view that the death penalty is an inhumane form of punishment which violates the most fundamental of all human rights--the right to life. The conviction that capital punishment should be so regarded led Australia to promote actively the second optional protocol against the death penalty to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to which we became a party in October of last year.

ANSWER.PARA: Our position on capital punishment has been conveyed to a great many foreign governments when we have made representations on behalf of individuals sentenced to death. So far as Papua New Guinea is concerned, on several occasions we have made our views clear to the Government of that country. I myself raised the matter with Mr Namaliu when he visited Australia on 2 September and I made perfectly clear what the Government's position was.

In relation to the second question about the United States, we have again regularly raised our concerns with the United States authorities at various levels over the death penalty. We will certainly consider raising the issue again during the Bush visit. But I do note that in the United States it is the state governments that are essentially responsible for the application of the death penalty and it has in the past usually been the state governments to which we have made those appropriate representations.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Since that touches on the answer I have given, I should table this press release to clarify the full answer to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. —-As I said, I think, in the primary response to the first question, we do not jump into Lake Burley Griffin at the first glimmer of an Industry Commission report. If there is anything to the answer I have given that he cares to add, I will supply it.

—-I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services to the advertisements by Mutual Community in the papers and on television in South Australia. A newspaper advertisement implies that one will go blind waiting for cataract operations under Medicare but not with Mutual Community. Can the Minister say what the facts are about emergency surgery and Medicare provisions? Can he tell the Senate about waiting times for private hospitals? Can he say whether these advertisements might contravene the Trade Practices Act regarding advertising?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

They show a series of sporting accidents and suggest that the treatments for the resultant injuries are elective surgery for which the accident victim would have to wait many months for treatment if he or she were not insured. Such a suggestion is patently absurd. Accident and emergency treatment, unlike elective surgery, is not subject to waiting lists. I am surprised that the health Ministers in Victoria and South Australia have not reacted to this slur on the accident and emergency departments of their hospitals.

ANSWER.PARA: Similarly with the newspaper advertisement, it is mischievous and a slur on the medical profession to assert that, even where there may be waiting lists for elective ophthalmology, serious cases will not be dealt with according to medical need. —-I refer the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to today's Sydney Morning Herald article about claims that, if the third runway is built, aircraft delays and diversions will be far greater than predicted in the EIS. What does this mean for the use of the east-west runway? How would this affect any future plans to downgrade the east-west runway?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I did notice that story spread all over the front page of today's Sydney Morning Herald. I trust that the newspaper will give as much prominence to the facts as it has given to the fiction. I will have the opportunity of discussing this matter with Mr Lockwood, who prepared the report, when I meet him tomorrow, along with a number of other anti-third runway people.

ANSWER.PARA: The claims that Mr Lockwood made are fairly dramatic, that is, that the EIS is fundamentally flawed in that the east-west runway will not be taken out of service and that the actual percentage of aircraft movements that will have to continue on the east-west runway because of adverse wind conditions at the airport will be `a minimum' of 23 per cent up to 30 per cent of aircraft movements.

I have no difficulty at all with Mr Lockwood's data on the actual wind conditions at Sydney Airport, but there are fundamental flaws in the assumption that he made in leaping to the conclusions that he has based on that data. Principally those flaws are found in the assumptions he has made on the cross-wind tolerances of the aircraft that utilise Sydney; the overly conservative criteria that he has used for the cross-wind conditions of the airport; and the assumptions he has made about the time for which Sydney Airport is subject to instrument landing conditions.

To indicate how dramatically flawed this information is, rather than the theoretical models used by Mr Lockwood, I rely on the statistics--the data from the control tower at the airport--about the actual number of actual movements of actual aircraft that have had to be diverted to the east-west runway because of weather conditions.

I should like to refer briefly to the information which is contained in the supplement to the EIS. I refer to table 10.3 which is contained on page 10-11, which is data on aircraft movements which is actually taken from the tower at Sydney Airport. The table deals with aircraft movements on the east-west runway when the north-south runway was unavailable owing to 20-knot cross-wind conditions. This data has been collected over a three-year period, from 1987 to 1989, and is taken from the tower at Sydney Airport.

I will not give a detailed breakdown, but the bottom line of this table indicates that the total number of aircraft, that is, jet and non-jet aircraft, that actually had to be diverted to the east-west runway because of these wind conditions over that three-year period represented 1.63 per cent, as distinct from the assertions all over the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald this morning from Mr Lockwood that a minimum of 23 per cent of these movements would mysteriously somehow in the future have to be diverted. Coming from Darwin, I am used to cyclones, but I have not noticed too many in Sydney on a daily basis. I look forward to discussing, with Mr Lockwood when I meet him tomorrow, this data that has been given so much prominence on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald.

The facts are that the supplement to the EIS reaffirms the data in the original draft environmental impact statement: that by the year 2010 an average of 99 per cent of all aircraft movements will be able to be safely conducted on the two parallel runways, which will mean that the ongoing need for the east-west runway will be dramatically scaled down.

This, of course, is a crucial question, as everyone knows, because the aggregate figures of the reduction in people seriously affected by aircraft noise at Sydney, which is the major environmental issue, are absolutely determined by the removal from operational use of the east-west runway. The position will be that 99 per cent of aircraft will be able to utilise the runways to a position where, by the year 2010, the movements will be reduced on the east-west runway from 72,500 in 1988 to approximately 3,600 in the year 2010.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Minister for Industrial Relations, who is a strong advocate of the various accords. Why has his Government inflicted wage restraint on Australian workers through the various accords, yet steadfastly refused to implement policies that would enable wage restraint to be turned into productivity growth which, in turn, would provide jobs, job security and an increased standard of living for Australian workers? Why has productivity growth in Australia been so dismally low under the various accords?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The word `inflicted' stands out as a weird word in this context because people know that the accord is what it says: it is an agreement, an accord, between two consenting parties. In this case, one party represents the work force of Australia--the trade union movement--and the other party represents the Government of Australia. It is true that the accord has led to wage restraint. That has been applauded by, among others, the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and so on. The point that the Opposition, and now Senator Vanstone, appears not to understand is really quite a simple one, and if they apply themselves they will understand it.

ANSWER.PARA: The point is that the accord is about living standards; it is not about wage levels. The accord talks about the level of taxation, the benefit of the social wage, the overall questions of equity and fairness in the work force, as well as the wage itself, and takes a holistic, not a narrow, view of what constitutes living standards. Therefore it was that we compensated for reductions in the real wage by cutting taxation; therefore it was that we compensated for wage restraint by introducing Medicare as a major social benefit in the community. By interaction between these two things, most recently in September last year, we bought out an entire wage round--which saved the Australian community and the employers the cost of a wage increase at that time--with a tax cut.

The point is that wages growth, as compared with the consumer price index, because of the buying out of the wages round, will appear less but living standards were preserved and the purchasing power of the pockets of wage earners was not reduced. That is the simple point. If the Opposition applies itself, it will see that this is a very sound idea and a way in which an economy such as ours can grow.

The honourable senator talks about a productivity increase. We wanted--and submitted to the Industrial Relations Commission in the last national wage case increase--to provide guidelines for direct bargaining in order to facilitate growth and productivity, among other things. The Commission made another decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister was asked as the bottom line: why has productivity growth in Australia been so dismally low under the accords? He has not answered that part of the question. Do I take it that the Minister denies that productivity growth-- GDP per hour--has been markedly less on average under the Hawke Government than it was under the Fraser Government? Does he deny that it has fallen in six of the last nine quarters? How does he explain its being so poor compared with the OECD performance? How does he explain its being so poor compared with the performance of our Asian trading partners? I come back to the original question: why has productivity growth in Australia been so dismally low if the accord is so good?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is a really laboured question. Senator Vanstone is trying to turn the silk purse of the accord into a sow's ear and failing dismally. The benefit of the accord is best demonstrated in a reduction of unit labour costs in the economy. Those figures, which I do not have to hand, can be adduced. That is one element of what goes to make up productivity.

ANSWER.PARA: Productivity, if I may say so, is made up of a number of other elements, including the type of technology used, the type of investment, the ability to win markets and the ability to sell goods. It is made up of all of those things. If the honourable senator does not have a basic economic primer as to how one calculates productivity and how the elements of it go to make productivity growth, then I suggest she telephone me after Question Time and I will supply her with one.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Last Thursday, Senator Boswell asked a question of my colleague Senator Evans regarding the importing of grain and went on to ask whether wheat growers could initiate anti-dumping measures while the wheat is in transit to Australia. I have obtained an answer to this question because it is relevant to my portfolio. I will refer to only the last part of the answer. The answer is fairly long and I will seek leave to have the whole answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of the answer says that last week, at the request of the Minister for Small Business and Customs, the Australian Customs Service spoke with, and wrote to, the Grains Council about the possibility of the Council lodging an application under the anti-dumping legislation. A meeting between the Council and Customs has been arranged for 17 October to further discuss key issues relevant to the Council's claim. I seek leave to incorporate the whole answer in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The answer read as follows--
An anti-dumping case can be mounted against any goods on its way to Australia. The Customs Act 1901 clearly allows for an application to be made on goods likely to be imported.

However, the application would need to justify the basis of that likelihood. Any advice from the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) concerning preliminary applications for import, depending on the nature and timeliness of that advice, may prove sufficient to justify the likelihood of imports.

Claims have been made that the prospective grain to be imported into Australia would be subsidised. For this, the application would need to show the amount and the form of subsidy. As evidence of this, practice has been that applications provide a copy of the relevant legislative base for payment of the subsidy in the country of export.
In terms of material injury, the application would need to show the likely effect of imports. The legislation sets out relevant considerations in this area.

Last week, at the request of the Minister for Small Business and Customs, the Australian Customs Service spoke with and wrote to the Grains Council about the possibility of the Council lodging an application under the anti-dumping legislation. A meeting between the Council and Customs has been arranged for 17 October to further discuss key issues relevant to the Council's claim.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-A couple of days ago Senator Calvert asked a question about the Aurora Australis, and I have some additional information. The Aurora Australis encountered two mechanical problems: a leaking propeller shaft oil seal, which was discovered prior to the vessel's departure; and the breakdown of an oceanographic winch, which occurred en route to Macquarie Island. Following the winch breakdown, a revised data collection schedule was developed by the participating scientists. This program is now being followed, subject to weather conditions. The data collected this season will be a valuable contribution to the five-year world ocean circulation experiment, in which Australia is a significant partner.

ANSWER.PARA: As a result of the delays, the voyage is expected to return to Hobart four days behind its original schedule. The cost implications of the delays in terms of salaries and so on are still being assessed. During the lay-up period prior to the commencement of the voyage, the vessel had only a caretaker crew aboard. The oceanographic winch was tested statically at the wharf under a simulated load and the owners confirmed to the Antarctic division that they had proved the satisfactory performance of the winch. The legal implications of any costs borne by the Commonwealth as a result of the above problems are currently being examined by the Antarctic division in conjunction with the Office of the Australian Government Solicitor.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Honourable senators would be aware that over the past 18 months there has been a major project to modernise and improve the operations of the Hansard Division of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. INTERJECT.PARA: A major component of the modernisation project is the introduction of in-house publishing of the Daily and Weekly Hansards. This involves Hansard taking responsibility for laying out, formatting and paginating the entire Daily Hansard--tasks previously carried out by the Australian Government Publishing Service. Hansard then provides camera-ready, fully prepared material to the Australian Government Publishing Service for printing only.

The benefits of in-house publishing are two-fold: the first is that there are very substantial reductions in costs to the Parliament; the second is that the Daily Hansards will be available noticeably earlier, both the printed copies and the electronic version stored on the Parliamentary DataBase System.

Honourable senators may be interested to know that for the last two sitting weeks the Daily Hansard for the Senate has been published in-house by Hansard. This follows the introduction in the previous sitting fortnight of in-house publishing for the House of Representatives Daily Hansard. The Daily and Weekly Hansards for both chambers are now published in-house by Hansard.

I am sure that honourable senators would agree that this is a significant step by the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff as it will allow the Parliament to take advantage of future developments in publishing technology with the consistent objective of continuing to improve the services provided to the Parliament.

Aside from the significant reductions in printing costs which will now occur, it has been noticeable that the Daily Hansard has been delivered to Parliament House every day of this sitting fortnight at or before 9 o'clock in the morning.

In addition, Hansard has published in-house the reports of a number of hearings of Senate legislative and general purpose standing committees, where those committees have been considering Bills referred by the Senate. Hansard reports of future Estimates hearings will also be published in-house.

The changes which have occurred in Hansard would not have been possible without the commitment, professionalism and dedication of all staff of the Division. Major improvements have been made to all facets of Hansard's operations and I congratulate those concerned on their successful implementation.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Advance to the Minister for Finance

DEBATE.SUB2.TITLE: Supporting Applications of Issues from the Advance to the Minister for Finance

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the documents.

The September Advance to the Minister for Finance--we have to take document No. 3 and document No. 4 together--contains some very major items of expenditure, some of which are explainable in terms of the expenditure being required prior to the passage of the Budget Bills.

There are several items in the appropriations in the Advance to the Minister for Finance for which no appropriations appear to have been made this year. It would appear that appropriations should have been made. At first glance it would seem that some of the requirements being sought through the Advance to the Minister for Finance should never have arisen. They are indicative of very bad management and Budget planning by the departments concerned.

For example, although the amount is relatively small, there is an application for funds to the Advance to the Minister for Finance of $5,387 from the Department of Administrative Services for royal commissions and inquiries. No appropriation has been given despite the fact that there was advance information that that money would be required.

A similar situation arises in respect of the request for funds to refund payments made by overseas students unable to undertake or complete courses of study in Australia under the Overseas Students (Refunds) Act. Although there was money appropriated in the Budget the amount of expenditure will sufficiently exceed that amount; this again requires a use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance which should not have been required.

There are other examples of similar situations. For example--I am sure my colleague Senator Michael Baume will comment on this, so I will not pursue it in detail--the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories asked for funds. Again it should have had appropriations accorded to it, but no appropriations were made. Similarly, although the Budget for 1991-92 allows for payment of up to $31.2m to wheat growers as compensation for sanctions against Iraq, there appears to be no Budget appropriation for that.

I draw those matters to the attention of the Senate. We have spoken many times in the past on the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I believe that the Advance is being used improperly on frequent occasions--I have made that point many times, as have my colleagues. On this occasion I believe there is, subject to further scrutiny, quite clear evidence that many of the items being claimed for usage in the September Advance to the Minister for Finance should have been taken account of and the Government should have been aware of them before they arose. It is just another example of the absolute sloppiness and bad administration for which this Government is increasingly becoming recognised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to join my colleague Senator Short in expressing concern about what appears to be clear incompetence by the Government in this area of funding of Government activities. We are still dealing with the Budget; it has not passed yet. There is no doubt, as we have seen, that various elements of the Budget have been subject to major revision, such as health services. Senator Walters pointed out yesterday how ludicrous it is for us to try to pass appropriations while in fact the Government is still changing them.

SPEECH.PARA: We have an example where the Government decided on 15 July 1991 to provide $800,000 in the current financial year and $100,000 in the next financial year to the Australian Electoral Commission to assist it in the costs of the 1992 ACT election. I have no knowledge of or concern about the merits of that decision.

All that is evident to me is that the decision was made on 15 July and the Budget was brought down on 20 August. The Budget made no provision for funding the decision made on 15 July. That decision was made more than a month before the Budget. I do not know whether the Government is doing this deliberately, whether it is trying to fudge the level of Government expenditure or trying to understate it, when it knows perfectly well that it will be spending more than it is stating in its Budget Papers. This is a clear example of that. It is a relatively small amount for the Government--$800,000 this year and $100,000 next year; almost $1m.

One would think that, if the Government had a decent level of integrity, it would at least mention in the papers--at least mention somewhere--the fact that it was to have additional expenditure. Frankly, I cannot see why more than a month does not provide it with more than enough time to have included this in the Budget Papers. The explanation for the need to have this extra money while we are still debating the Budget is:
The Electoral Commission is currently undertaking preliminary work in respect of the election.
That is the Australian Capital Territory election in 1992. It goes on:
The Commission has now requested reimbursement of $237,600 being costs incurred to date on preliminary work. The requirement is urgent as the AEC has requested payment by the end of August.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I present the report of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances on scrutiny by the Committee of regulations made under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The report is a case study of the scrutiny by the Committee of regulations made under the Sex Discrimination Act 1984. This is now finally completed, exactly seven years after that Act was proclaimed to come into operation and although the process was somewhat protracted the result is entirely satisfactory. An open-ended discretion granted to the Executive to extend indefinitely Commonwealth, State and Territory laws which provided for sexual discrimination was first limited and then removed. The position now is that the Executive has no longer any power to prolong the operation of discriminatory laws, as compared to the original position where there were no limits at all on its power. The Sex Discrimination Act, following the insistence of the Committee and a full debate by parliament, now operates as it should as a stand-alone document with the few exemptions to its provisions provided in the Act itself.

In scrutinising regulations made under the Act the Committee employed virtually every option open to it. These included writing to Ministers; asking for a special additional report from the Committee's legal adviser, Emeritus Professor Douglas Whalan; giving a protective notice of motion of disallowance; accepting an undertaking to amend the regulations; being briefed by senior officers of the Department; and then accepting an undertaking to amend the parent Act. The report describes all these actions in detail.

During its scrutiny of the regulations the Committee dealt with three Ministers--the then Attorney-General, the Hon. Lionel Bowen, MP; the Attorney-General, the Hon. Michael Duffy, MP; and the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, Senator Tate. As usual, these Ministers were courteous and helpful, and we commend them for this commitment to the principles of the Committee. We are also grateful to the officers of the Human Rights Branch of the Attorney-General's Department who briefed the Committee.

The Committee is very pleased to table this report as an example of the way in which it carries out its mandate from the Senate to ensure that delegated legislation does not breach parliamentary propriety or personal liberties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I speak as Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, and support the comments of Senator Giles on this report. The report is particularly notable because it deals with breaches of two of the principles of the Committee. We first considered that the regulations in question were defective because they breached the first of the Committee's four principles or terms of reference. The principle is that delegated legislation must be in accordance with the parent Act. The principle is interpreted broadly, in this case the Committee being concerned that the regulations may breach the spirit of the parent Act. This was the deficiency first raised by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: However, after some years of dealing with a succession of defective instruments, all of which appeared to breach the spirit of the parent Act, the Committee considered that the whole scheme was so fundamentally flawed that it also breached the other principle of the Committee which is designed to protect parliamentary propriety, that is, that delegated legislation must not contain matter more appropriate for inclusion in an Act of parliament.

It is only rarely that the Committee invokes this principle. Nevertheless, it is an important principle going to the heart of parliamentary propriety. In this case, I am glad to say that the Minister accepted the views of the Committee and undertook to amend the parent Act so that it was not legally possible for the Executive to prolong discriminatory laws even if it should wish to do so. I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: I have one answer to a question that Senator Patterson asked earlier. It concerned the comparisons between the ABS and Department of Social Security data. It also classifies a person as employed if, among other things, he or she has worked for one hour or more during the survey period. The ABS series includes unemployed persons whose spouse is working, irrespective of income, whereas JSA and Newstart recipients are subject to income and assets tests. The ABS series includes persons being paid pensions but looking for work, for example, sole parents in receipt of a sole pension looking for work.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether Mrs Kelly has received much advice that favours the making of the payments, except advice from me. She still has the matter under consideration. In fact, as a result of the meeting with Mrs Loydell, I have asked for a meeting with the Minister to discuss this issue. I asked for that this afternoon and I imagine that I will meet with her in the next week or so and see if I can get a definite final response on that question. I will leave the timing of either announcement, however, to her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would be more than happy to wait until whenever Mrs Kelly might make an announcement, providing it is appropriate. I certainly would not even ask that she let me know before she answers. I would just be so happy to have the right answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I will waste a minute and say--and some of my colleagues will not appreciate this--that the Minister's reputation in the Ravenshoe area has not been good because of history. But whenever I have anything to do with Ravenshoe I say to the people there that he has been exceedingly generous and supportive in recent times, particularly since he has been Minister. I for one do appreciate that, I think he is doing the right thing at this time.

I certainly agree with the Minister that it is a case very deserving of support and hopefully his departmental advisers will take heed of what he has said. I might say to Senator Richardson that I will certainly make known his comment that he has supported it--not that Senator Richardson is incapable of making his own views known, but I will assist him in that.

I would say again for the benefit of the departmental advisers that I can understand the reluctance in that the Department certainly does not want to create a precedent. I can appreciate that fully. I will not go through the grounds again except to say that it is documented in speeches I and other people have made and in letters that have been received that this is an exceptional case, that it would not be used as a precedent and that it would be quite appropriate to make a one-off grant in this particular instance. The amount of money involved is very small. It ranges, depending on which figures one uses, from $250,000 to, I think, $750,000. There is still money in the structural adjustment package or the `up to' figure that might be able to be used.

I just point out that the Commonwealth spends money in many other ways. Under subprogram 6.4, I think we spent $1m in the last year on consultancies. This area, which means so much to real people, is one thing that I think could well be looked at. I appreciate the Minister's support for that.
The Minister has referred to a Mrs Loydell but the name does not mean anything to me. I wonder whether the Minister might just indicate who the lady is.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I was referring to Robyn Loydell, who is fairly well known around Australia as a timber worker's wife and who has been heavily involved in promoting the cause of logging, logging and ever more logging. I cannot say that Mrs Loydell is a close friend of mine, having clashed with her on a number of occasions. But I did say that we were achieving a milestone today as this is the first thing she and I have agreed on. Hopefully it is a portent of bigger things to come.

—-The Minister has buoyed me to such an extent with his last answer that I am almost reluctant to ask some nasty questions that I want to put to him. In answer to a question, I was told that Kinhill Pty Ltd was paid $100,385 for an evaluation of the structural adjustment package. Senator Baume asked for a list of consultancies in the Department. In the area that I just mentioned there is almost $1m worth of them. I understand that the Kinhill payment is shown at only $20,000. This seems to be a different figure. I was wondering whether anyone might be able to explain to me why there is a difference.

—-I can assist Senator Macdonald. The reason for a difference in the two figures is that Kinhill's work has not been finalised yet so it has only been part paid. As I understand it, the figure that you were given in the first place is correct. It is just that it will be some time before all of that is paid to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to ask the Minister a question in relation to Tully-Millstream, which was discussed at the Estimates Committee. Before doing so, I refer again to the list of consultancies. I note that a group named Energy Policy and Analysis Pty Ltd was paid $2,500 and then $5,000 to review previous advice concerning the Tully-Millstream task force report and, secondly, to review the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric scheme. What is Energy Policy and Analysis Pty Ltd and who are the directors or people who do the work for that group? I am particularly interested to know whether it is an offshoot of Griffith University.

SPEECH.PARA: Can the Minister indicate to me what those consultancy reports were all about? I ask that question in the light of some answers given at the Estimates Committee hearing in respect of Tully-Millstream. It was indicated that the Department was reviewing the task force report; that the Department was waiting for further information from the Queensland Government; and that the Department was doing certain things. If the Department is doing it, I ask why Energy Policy and Analysis Pty Ltd had to be engaged to do this particular consultancy work.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My understanding is that the principal of the firm to which Senator Macdonald has referred is Hugh Saddler, who is a Canberra-based energy consultant. So I do not think there is any connection with Griffith University. It is not unusual for departments to bring in consultants when they are conducting reviews of this kind. As I understand it, the task force report touches upon some technical matters and this kind of technical expertise in power generation is not necessarily resident in the Department. Clever as the officers are, they are not omniscient and, on this occasion, they brought in an outsider who is an expert.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In relation to those consultancy reports, it is shown that $11,822 was paid to a Mr W. Reid for media liaison and public relations in Cairns. The reason he was engaged, apparently, was that the Department lacked the resources and expertise. Can the Minister tell me what that is about? If he cannot, will he undertake to let me know later?

SPEECH.PARA: While he is at it, $59,350 was paid to a Dr G. Tracey for scientific advice on wet tropics and another $2,000 was paid to a Mrs R. Tracey for a national rainforest conservation program guide to Australian rainforests. I am wondering whether the Minister might either be able to tell me now, or undertake to tell me later, what those consultancies were about and what the need for them was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-If we are speaking of Geoff Tracey, he is someone who worked for CSIRO for many years. He is perhaps the expert on north Queensland rainforests; if not, he is awfully close to it. If ever one is going to tour a rainforest in north Queensland, one should take him along. I did, and it makes it a much more interesting and informative experience. I did not know that the Department had hired Mr Tracey. If it has, that is good; I am delighted to hear it. I am not sure who Mrs R. Tracey is. We will have to take that on board. I will find that out.

SPEECH.PARA: The other person you referred to--Mr Reid--was a person assisting the rainforest unit in Cairns. When I was in Cairns we also had a press person employed at the rainforest unit; in fact that person went on to become my press secretary. So I know that was done back in 1987 or 1988, and I assume this is a continuation of that function.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Twelve thousand dollars appears to be a lot of money to pay for press consultancies for a unit that is a very small part of the overall Department. The Department certainly does not lack expertise in publicity. I will await the Minister's further advice or clarification.

—-It is not simply a matter of writing press releases. I have not met Mr Reid--I do not know the person--but such a person is expected to assist in the provision of information. There is a lot of material produced by the rainforest unit which is pumped out into the local community and to visitors to the rainforest areas. So the person concerned is there not only to write press releases or to handle press conferences if someone visits or if there is an announcement to make but also, on a more permanent basis, to provide information. New information about rainforests is so easy to find. We know so little about them; we are learning and, as we continue to learn, we have to share the knowledge.

—-Finally, I take the Minister to the Estimates Committee hearings where we spoke about the Tully-Millstream hydro-electric evaluation and where, as at 4 September, it was indicated to me that the Department was still considering or evaluating the Tully-Millstream task force report done by the Queensland Government at some fairly great expense but that the Department had been held up because it was stalled by the Queensland Government in getting some information. Can the Minister, or the officers through the Minister, indicate how far that evaluation of the Tully-Millstream report has got and where we go from here in relation to it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-When I was the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories I can recall when asked about the Tully-Millstream project, after going to Ravenshoe again to visit the offices of the electricity authority to look at the plans for the protection of endangered species--the Atherton Antechinus and another one; there were two as I remember--having a look at the proposals. It is fashionable for environment groups and environment Ministers to be critical of, in particular, power generating authorities in the way they do business. I was quite impressed and I thought in Queensland they had really tried.

SPEECH.PARA: My view of it after that was that, given that the World Heritage agreement itself allows for acts of economic necessity, the dam could go ahead provided there was a demonstrated need for the power, and that meant looking at options other than a hydro-electric scheme there. That attitude has been maintained by the Commonwealth. A working group was set up by the Commonwealth and the Queensland Government.

I could get Senator MacDonald some further information, and I will endeavour to do so. But my understanding is that the Commonwealth presented to the Queensland Government some suggestions on what the other options might be. The Queensland Government decided as a result of those suggestions that further work needed to be done on them. The Queensland Government has therefore set up its own internal processes to deal with this and to provide the Commonwealth with further responses. So at the moment the Commonwealth is awaiting some further information from Queensland before a final decision is made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I appreciate what the Minister says, and I appreciate that one cannot really anticipate when agencies one does not control will supply the information needed. However, can the Minister give me some rough timetable of when the Commonwealth's part of the task force report review might be undertaken?

SPEECH.PARA: I notice in the list of consultancies I referred to that a number of people have been paid by the Department to do reports into wind power and alternative forms of power and energy generation and distribution by Energy Policy and Analysis Pty Ltd. They were submissions to the Industry Commission inquiry, but no doubt they would be of assistance in pursuing the Commonwealth's investigations into the task force report. Can the Minister indicate when we are likely to get the final Commonwealth position on the report?

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am advised that the Queensland Government has said that it will respond by the end of November. I imagine that means that by early in the new year the Commonwealth will be in a position to give an indication of its attitude. Obviously, it is a matter that Mrs Kelly will have to take to Cabinet. Cabinet does not meet in January, so I suppose we will be looking at a Cabinet submission in February or March. We can let our attitude be known once that has been done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I feel churlish saying this, for the reasons I mentioned before, but I forget which side of the debate this Minister is on when it comes to fast tracking. With Senator Button's call for fast tracking of projects and not having them pigeonholed and put aside in any government department--we can only talk about the Commonwealth Government departments--if the Tully-Millstream project were to go ahead as recommended in the task force report, it would provide quite a boost to employment in the Cairns-Innisfail area and would be a good project that would encourage industry in north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept what the Minister says, that the Government will get the response in November and it will go to Cabinet in February. While I understand that governments are big and the wheels have, of necessity, to move slowly, these are the sorts of things that get tied up in the red tape and the green tape, to use an expression that is getting more prominence these days. I urge the Minister to pursue Senator Button's line and not let these things remain too long in the departmental pigeonholes or anywhere else. I would not suggest it is the Commonwealth Department that is doing that. I urge the Minister to use his best endeavours to make sure that the Queensland Government supplies the information as quickly as possible so that the project, if it is to go ahead, can do so at the earliest possible time, which would have a big influence on unemployment in far north Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have been fairly careful not to make any comments on fast tracking thus far and I will not break my duck here. The list of projects that have been looked at for fast tracking, it should be noted, contained almost none that had a delay caused by environmental reasons. Most were for economic, not environmental, reasons. That does not surprise me; I knew that would be the case. One must look beyond the hype, and very often people do not do that.

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of Tully-Millstream, as I have said, my attitude is on record. If it is shown that there is a need for the power and that this is the most cost effective way of satisfying that need, I will support it. But I have not seen any documentation yet, so I cannot express my view. But it is in everyone's interest, including the environmentalists, to get a decision on this as soon as possible.

Most important to this decision is the Queensland Government which has been wanting it to be as speedy a process as possible. I know that Premier Goss and the relevant Ministers are fast tracking their own approach to this. We are actually dealing with very big questions when it comes to power generation and the various alternatives to it. That involves hundreds of millions of dollars and obviously we cannot fix it overnight; it takes a bit of time. I know that the Queensland Government is working very hard. I can guarantee that our processes will be very quick, but we rely upon the receipt of information from Queensland. It is promised by the end of November and I am pretty sure that we can stick to the timetable I have outlined.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I crave the indulgence of the Committee and more particularly my colleagues to ask one final question. Does the Minister have a series of proposals from the Queensland Government in relation to the structural adjustment package concerning the Fraser Island and Great Sandy region? If so, are the Minister and the Department happy with the proposals for the package put forward by the Queensland Government? Are the Department and the Minister satisfied that the package and the proposal to administer the package will avoid the problems, to put it mildly--or fiasco to put it more accurately--that have occurred in Ravenshoe? Is the Minister satisfied that the administration and the program will ensure, as far as possible, that there will be no overall loss of employment opportunities in the Maryborough, Hervey Bay, Fraser Island and Great Sandy region as a result of the package proposed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My understanding is that the Commonwealth and the Queensland Government agreed on guidelines for how money from this package for the Fraser Island and Great Sandy region might be spent. Therefore, the Queensland Government will have to work within those guidelines when deciding upon which projects will go ahead. But the Commonwealth itself will not be approving projects. They will be approved by the Queensland Government. What we have done is provide the money and agree on guidelines as to how it will be spent. I do not expect we will be given a list of projects. I think it is a matter which the honourable senator should take up with the Queensland Government if he wishes to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly, Premier Goss is anxious to maintain employment in the region. That is why he has sought quite considerable Commonwealth funds for it. If he sticks within the guidelines, I am sure he will make sure that most, if not all, of the people affected will have employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I warn the Minister gratuitously that he gave money to someone he expected would spend it properly the last time. I would have thought, with the value of hindsight, that he might have at least kept a veto over the next group of people to whom he gave money to spend to make sure that those people did not also run off with the money, as may have occurred in the past.

—-In an era when I think both sides of politics are looking to see the Commonwealth rationalise arrangements with the States, this is an important example of micro-economic reform which I would not like to see reversed.

—-There being no further questions on subprogram 6.4, the Committee will now deal with subprogram 6.5 relating to the environment and subprogram 6.6 relating to the Supervising Scientist and the Alligator Rivers Region Research Institute.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-A number of important issues were canvassed at the Estimates committee hearings. I would particularly like to take the time of the Committee for a few moments to deal with the issue of the proposed EPA and also the Office of the Supervising Scientist in the Northern Territory. With regard to the proposed establishment of the new EPA--since the answers were provided to the Committee on 4 September and, I think, subsequently to a couple of the questions taken on notice, has there been any advance with regard to the dates for the establishment of the new agency as a formal statutory body? Have there been any changes with regard to the proposals to bring forward a legislative proposal for the consideration of the Parliament?
—-Unfortunately, the answer is no to those questions.

—-Have there been discussions with any senior public servants or other people in the private sector about a suitable person to head the new Environment Protection Agency? What discussions have taken place with senior people of the rank that we would expect could take up this sort of position, particularly as the Department has already established the agency within its umbrella and we have noted that there is to be a considerably expanding number of people employed in the agency throughout the financial year? I am keen to ascertain what discussions have taken place with particular people. I would also like to know whether anyone has canvassed with Dr Fry, the current Supervising Scientist, whether he might head that agency?

—-As I understand it, the Department has advertised the position and has received quite a number of applications both from within the Public Service and from outside it. We will shortly be sifting through those to make some recommendations as to the right person for the job. As a matter of policy, we do not reveal who applies for jobs so I do not know whether Dr Fry has applied. I do not think we have actually asked him to apply so, if he has applied, it is as a result of his own desires.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-Will the appointment to that position be filled through the normal processes of the Department or is it a position that will need the imprimatur of Cabinet or the Minister?
—-I do not think this goes to Cabinet. It is a Public Service position which will be filled in the normal way. I do not believe it is in that run of positions that have to go to Cabinet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-I now turn to the issues regarding the Office of the Supervising Scientist. I note that some detail was provided in answer to the questions that were taken on notice about the report referred to as the Taylor report, which is a review of the Office of the Supervising Scientist. The review was completed by Professor Taylor on 22 November 1989 and was in fact tabled by Senator Richardson in this place on 18 December 1989. At the time of the Estimates consideration of this matter, there had been no formal response with regard to the 47 recommendations contained in that report to the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the questions that I asked, a quite comprehensive document has been supplied to the Committee setting out the issues that have been addressed and the current status. But it still concerns me that, of the 47 recommendations made by Professor Taylor, some 28 have not yet been concluded or established. In fact, the common phrase used throughout the document presented to the Committee in regard to each of these 28 recommendations is, `requires consideration and response by Government'.

Given the very serious nature of that particular review, and many of the issues that relate not only to finance but also to the operation of the Office of the Supervising Scientist, what is the timetable in which the Government proposes to actually give consideration to these recommendations that have now been outstanding for some two years? When does it intend to address the very serious issues that relate to the environment, mining, Aboriginals, the future operation and structure of the Office of the Supervising Scientist--in fact, the whole ambit of the operation of such an important office? I would have thought, given the priorities of the Government with regard to the issues of the environment and Kakadu National Park, that this issue would not have been left standing for some two years.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I understand it, the Department has prepared a response. It will be lodged for consideration by Cabinet in a month. I imagine that means it will be considered by Cabinet within two months. A resolution of this matter is at hand.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: -Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-To what extent is the Office of the Supervising Scientist currently applying any of its resources or activities to the operations at Roxby Downs?
—-None.

—-I noted that, in the response that was given to the Committee in detailing these 47 recommendations, there was comment with regard to the activities in South Australia. Whilst I acknowledge that they met with the response that these issues required the consideration and response of government, I am surprised that none of the technical expertise of the Office of the Supervising Scientist has in any way been seconded, recruited or used to work alongside the important work that the Government must be undertaking in its review of Roxby Downs. Therefore, I am surprised by the Minister's unequivocal answer that it is absolutely none in respect of that particular issue. I just ask the Minister either to reiterate his statement or to expand further on these particular issues.

—-If one looks at the geography of Roxby Downs and the area which is covered by the Office of the Supervising Scientist, one notices quite considerable differences. Given that there are, therefore, different problems to be solved, there has not been a need for involvement by the Office of the Supervising Scientist. We are dealing with totally different regions, with totally different problems.
—-There being no further questions on subprograms 6.5 and 6.6, the Committee will now deal with program 8 `National Media Liaison Service funding'.

—-If the service does not provide services by way of transcripts or information to Opposition members and senators, why does it possess an index of Opposition members and senators on a computer database in its Parliament House office in Canberra?

—-I will find out. When one is compiling a database, one obviously makes it as wide as possible and tries to take into account people of importance. I think the people to whom Senator Newman refers are important. I am delighted to hear that the National Media Liaison Service has them so listed.
—-That does not answer my question.
—-I said I would find out.
—-In a minute or what?
—-I will take the question on notice and get a response from the office.

—-I trust the Minister understands that. If the service is not providing information or material to those people, what could possibly be the reason for having the details of them on its database? It is nothing to do with our importance or otherwise, by which the Minister might dismiss it.
—-That they don't supply.

—-Yes, that is correct. Why did the service not monitor any radio or television interviews made by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) when he recently announced the $2m advertising campaign on the ready reserves which, as honourable senators know, is an integral part of the Government's recently announced Defence Force structure review policy?

—-I do not think it has ever been possible for the National Media Liaison Service to monitor absolutely every statement made and interview given by Ministers. It has never been the case that it has done the lot. The National Media Liaison Service is not a huge service; there are not that many people. It has never been able to cover everything. I can only assume that because of the workload it was not able to cover Mr Bilney. Again, I will get a direct response from the service as to why it did not.

—-I thank the Minister. I point out that the announcement of the Defence Force structure review and the Ready Reserve was the largest Defence announcement since the White Paper which was introduced in 1987. I find it very strange. Why did the service accord it such low priority, especially when I understand there is some connection between the head of the service and the Minister concerned?

—-I am not sure what Senator Newman is alluding to by way of there being a connection between the head of the service and the Minister. If the National Media Liaison Service did not cover the Minister, it demonstrates that the connection is not so great as to outweigh professional judgment. Obviously, the service made a judgment on this question. I have already indicated that I am happy to check why. I suppose it depends on what else was on at the time. I do not know what else was on at that particular time. I will endeavour to get an explanation for Senator Newman.

—-I thank the Minister. What priorities does the service give in its media monitoring? How does it judge what it will monitor? This was an announcement which was also made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Does it mean to say that Mr Bilney sat in the Prime Minister's shadow or was the issue not important enough in the National Media Liaison Service's estimation of things? My recollection is that it was one of the major stories of the week, by anybody's judgment.

—-I can only keep repeating that I will get an answer from the National Media Liaison Service. It does not have a huge personnel. It has to prioritise assignments. It does not cover everything that the Prime Minister does either. I will get an answer.

—-I thank the Minister. I point out that Senator Baume made a reservation for this Committee hearing on the National Media Liaison Service and its funding. I would have thought that would have meant that we could expect, out of courtesy to the Senate, you to have people here who could answer questions on the National Media Liaison Service. I find it very strange that we have not been given that courtesy; it is most unacceptable.
—-The officers had a list of reservations and they did not have this one on it.
—-Mine does.

—-The one I have in front of me has them as to program 8. I am not disputing that. The officers have worked from a list that is in the report of Estimates Committee C. There is no page number, but it is at the back of the document where reservations are listed. There is the signature `Michael Baume' at the bottom of the page and he has nine reservations in relation to which he will examine the programs. They are not listed on that. That is why the Department has not brought someone along on this topic. There is no plot but obviously there has been an error.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister for that information. Perhaps we could come back to it later. In the meantime I have some other questions which perhaps can be taken on notice as a matter of convenience.

SPEECH.PARA: What records does the Department keep of the type of work that the service performs? Could I have a detailed breakdown of that work? I would like to know whether any staff training is given to the employees of the NMLS and, if so, at what cost. Does it include telephone manners and courtesy to inquirers and, if not, why not? When will performance based pay be introduced for the staff of NMLS?

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Chair might be able to assist in one small matter. The reservation to which Senator Newman refers was tabled today. Probably the Department was not able to act upon it because of that.
—-I will take those matters on notice.

—-I would like to put a question to the Minister about the National Media Liaison Service. I want to know why this group comes under DASETT and yet the funding comes out of the Department of Administrative Services. The reason I ask that question is that it appears to us that this is a deliberate attempt to confuse an issue in respect of a group of people upon whom we on this side look as highly suspect.

—-The administrative costs are borne by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The salaries are met by the Department of Administrative Services. The service reports directly to the Minister, Mrs Kelly--not to Minister Bolkus, who is at present in the chamber--in the same way as it reported directly to me when I was Minister. It is a matter of making sure that each body has a home. This was considered to be an appropriate home. I think that it has switched in a number of portfolios, but I think that it has resided with DASETT for rations and quarters for probably half its existence. It is a matter of judgment whether it is the best place or not, but certainly it is a reasonable place for it to reside.
—-Why is the funding of salaries out of the Department of Administrative Services when it reports to Minister Kelly?
—-The answer, as I understand it, is that the people concerned are employed under the parliamentary employees arrangements. They are all paid through the Department of Administrative Services.

—-I also wish to ask a question on the National Media Liaison Service. Could we have a full list of the people employed in the service and their salaries? Could we be told whether any of them are employed on the basis of consultancy arrangements of the type that we have seen expanded at a great rate under this Government?

—-With regard to consultancies I will find out the position. On the assumption that it is normal to produce lists of employees and their salaries--I am not sure that it is the normal practice--we will do it. There are always in these matters some privacy arrangements that are difficult for all employees. I can recall arguments that we have had on other occasions about the ABC not wanting to tell us what some people were paid. I do not think anyone in the NMLS will be in that category. But on the assumption that this is not an abnormal procedure, the answer is yes. I am told that apparently we have provided this information previously, so if it is correct to do so, we will update it.

—-There are some questions I wish to pursue, but since we have not got people here from the service, perhaps I could seek the guidance of the Chair as to whether we will be able to return to this when the staff are provided to give advice to the Minister.

—-The Chair cannot make that decision. I would point out that the reservation was in respect of funding, not the whole National Media Liaison Service. If there is a motion to that effect, that is outside the Chair's compass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will be moving a motion soon on several matters, which will include that. Clearly there are some matters that will have to come back.
