SPEECH.PARA: It would be easy to make some negative remarks about aspects of the trust accounts, but I do not believe that would be productive as the Opposition supports the establishment of trust accounts but recognises that they are still, to some degree, in their infancy and that there has been a fairly long learning process. It has meant the introduction of the well overdue accrual accounting system into the Government sector. We appreciate that this has meant a major change from traditional government accounting and, thus, a re-learning process, hence our patience.

It was with some relief that under the system of accrual accounting balance sheets, profit and loss accounts and notes to accounts were provided for each of the separate commercial units within DAS. I believe that the Minister floated the idea of a single trust account for a time, which we believe would have totally destroyed the original purpose of going to accrual accounting. It would have meant that cross-subsidisation inefficiencies would have been hidden from the Parliament.

There was also some concern expressed in the early days that with the move to trust accounts, accrual accounting and the section 41d profit and loss statements, a lot of the dollars would disappear and be charged off to other departments, and would not be available for scrutiny by the Parliament. This has been subsequently covered and not only this Parliament but also future parliaments will appreciate that. It would have meant that much information on the single trust accounts would have been simply privy to the Minister and the Department head.

The Opposition also welcomed the provision of details of trust accounts to Estimates committees. I realise that some problems were associated with them because they were unaudited, but we are happy to accept that because we believe that any subsequent changes would not be of any great magnitude. It could have been claimed that the revenue to DAS was at some other department's expenditure. From a parliamentary point of view, if that had occurred, it would have been virtually impossible to track. It would have made parliamentary scrutiny impossible.

As an overview it is somewhat annoying that, with the trust accounts in place, there continues to be a degree of secrecy in that, with one or two major exceptions--and I nominate Comcar as one of those--problems and potential problems do not seem to be highlighted. This means that Estimates committee members have to rely on leaks and fishing expeditions to dig out information. One cannot help but form the impression, rightly or wrongly, that some departmental officers have been put through a training course on damage control. This has certainly been the situation with most Estimates.

Having gone down the track of trust accounts and accrual accounting, it is neither appropriate nor in the interests of the Parliament or the various quasi commercial units that this attitude continues. It is an attitude which is not adopted by the responsible public companies. I believe that the Minister and departmental officers would save a lot of anguish and time at future Estimates committee hearings if this point is recognised and, as a result, more information is provided in the notes of the accounts, both good and bad.

What emerged from the trust accounts was that in the process of accrual accounting--and, I might say, proper costing, on which I congratulate the Department--an amount of 19.2 per cent of salaries was charged as employer superannuation. This is also referred to in the Committee report. This amount was handed over to the Government Retirement Benefits Office in the Department of Finance. It does not include employee contributions to SFIT, but does include the 3 per cent occupational superannuation which is invested. The 16.2 per cent balance of about $38m goes into Consolidated Revenue.

As everyone knows, the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme is unfunded from an employer's point of view. It would seem that some consideration should be given to the fact that DAS commercial units, which now operate as separate enterprises--if I could call them that--and which pay the equivalent of employer funding of super, would have been a good place to start for full funding. Maybe it is something that a future government will take into account when we have a surplus on our domestic account.

I noted one disconcerting feature throughout the quasi commercial units or trusts. When asked on what basis charges were made, the response inevitably was market rates. One of the features of competition, particularly in the service industries, is that there really is no such thing as a market rate. The impression I formed was that, rather than start with a series of costs and then determine what the rate should be, what these units have done--and I presume there is good reason for it--is start at what they perceive to be a market rate and then work backwards. This response raises the spectre of bidding for business and, if a loss is made, going back to the taxpayer to recover the loss. There is, therefore, not the same cost consciousness which applies in the private sector.

I make those remarks not in any way to be critical but simply as observations as a result of what is really the first full year of proper trust accounts with proper accrual accounting. I believe that it is in the best interests of the Department, the units and the future that those comments be taken on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In my remarks last night I raised the subject of the official observer mission for the inaugural direct elections for the Hong Kong Legislative Council. At the expiry of my time, I was enlarging on some of the recommendations of the mission concerning the electoral process. The next issue I wish to address relates to access to the media.

SPEECH.PARA: Currently in Hong Kong, there is a statutory prohibition on the usage of the television and radio for political endorsement or advertisement. This is perhaps pertinent to an issue currently before us in Australia. The mission regards this as a significant constraint on the candidates' ability to contact the voters in Hong Kong during the recently concluded election campaign. Given the influence of television and radio, these media could act as important campaign communication sources. The ban restricts the open expression of political opinion.

In a related issue, the electronic news media in Hong Kong also tends to practise a notable degree of self-censorship in the area of political coverage. In not wanting to appear biased for or against any candidate or opinion, many news broadcasts are essentially devoid of political coverage. Print journalists also practise forms of self-censorship, but to a lesser degree. This is a phenomenon which bodes ill for the future of political discourse in Hong Kong. If organisations or individuals begin to limit their discussion of political events or opinions because of a particular group's anticipated reactions, the fundamental freedom of expression is gradually eroded.

The electronic media was used by the Government for general get-out-the-vote messages and limited political education announcements. During the months immediately preceding the September 1991 Legislative Council elections, these advertisements were aired on a regular and frequent basis, although some observers have criticised the Government for lacking enthusiasm in its political education efforts.

Another issue is that of the geographical constituencies from which candidates were to be elected for the direct elections. The Governor-in-Council decided on nine two-member geographical constituencies with the two first-past-the-post candidates to be elected as opposed to a system of proportional representation. The number of eligible voters in each constituency varied dramatically with disparities of up to several hundred thousand. This led to charges of government manipulation of the elections.

While the physical features of Hong Kong, Kowloon and the New Territories were used to justify the boundaries used for this election, the excessive malapportionment evident certainly stretched the credibility of this argument. One popular proposal for addressing this problem was the establishment of an independent Boundaries Commission representative of the differing political viewpoints in Hong Kong and directly responsible to the Legislative Council instead of the Executive. Such a move would protect the Government from charges of impropriety as well as lend substantial credibility to the electoral process. Even with this proposal, there is the potential for stacking the Boundaries Commission with biased commissioners. This would do little to solve the issue at hand.

The matter of functional constituencies was also considered by the mission. One unique aspect of the Legislative Council electoral system is the existence of members elected from functional or profession-related constituencies. For example, members are elected to represent the teaching profession, the medical profession, trade unions, the Chamber of Commerce and the legal profession, to name just a few of the 21 functional constituencies which have been established to elect members to the Legislative Council.

Of course, the purpose of these functional constituencies is to elect a member of the Legislative Council who will particularly represent the interests of these specific occupational groups in law-making. The functional constituencies have been in existence since 1985 and the system provided for 21 functional members to be elected in 1991 on the Thursday prior to the Sunday direct election. So there were three more members of the Legislative Council elected from these functional constituencies than from directly elected geographic constituencies. This lends great importance to these positions in the scheme of Legislative Council elections.

One important aspect of the functional constituency system is the method of their election. Varying from constituency to constituency, some are elected by individual members of a profession, while others are elected by corporations or organisations within a profession. In that functional elections are legally regulated only to a minimal degree, there is substantial room for manipulation. For example, a social welfare organisation representing just 25 members may get one member elected just as another organisation representing 1,200 members does. Furthermore, each constituency establishes regulations for and administers its own electoral process. This may lead to questions regarding ballot security, tabulation and campaigning. In addition, with 12 functional seats uncontested in the 1991 elections, there was concern about apathy in these constituencies, the perceived importance of the elected posts and the possibility of electoral deals.

The most obvious critique of the system is the principle that a voter who is qualified to vote in the functional constituency may be allowed two or three votes while others are allowed only one vote. For example, a lawyer who sits on the board of directors of a commercial firm and lives in the Hong Kong East geographical constituency may vote three times: firstly, as a member of the legal community; secondly, as a board member through the commercial sector's functional constituency, so he has two functional constituency votes; and thirdly, in the direct elections. On the other hand, a shopkeeper may vote only once. This runs directly contrary to a professed system of fair representation. As an interim measure, en route to democracy, functional constituencies may have value, but not as a permanent part of the Hong Kong parliamentary scene.

Another issue on which the mission had some concerns was that of eligible voters. Currently, Hong Kong law requires seven years of residency to be eligible to vote and 10 years residency in order to run for office. The Basic Law is quite precise and restrictive in defining citizenship in Hong Kong. There could arise a problem with voters becoming disenfranchised during the transition process. In general, this is not difficult in today's Hong Kong. Voting eligibility can be lost due to death, moving out of Hong Kong or losing contact with the electoral office. The latter of these is the easiest category into which to fall. Moving within Hong Kong without active reregistration often results in loss of contact with the electoral office. There was a recent case of an entire housing estate in Hong Kong of some 30,000 voters falling off the rolls, even though only the addresses had changed.

Hong Kong's voting age is 21. This is an issue because the age of majority in Britain, as well as in China, is 18. Hong Kong recently changed its age of majority to 18, with the sole exception of voting privileges. This certainly seems out of the ordinary, but the decision is said to be based upon a hesitancy to politicise this energetic, vocal and often liberal age segment of the population.

Another issue is registration and voting. Handled as other administrative tasks in Hong Kong generally are, the electoral administration and the technical aspects of the registration, voting and tabulation of results appeared efficient, organised and fair. Few, if any, complaints were voiced to the mission about these aspects of the electoral system and widespread or systematic fraud was not in evidence in the elections.

One critical aspect of the technical regulation of the election which bears mention is in respect of impartial observers. The Legislative Council Electoral (Procedure) Regulations does not allow for the polling site to be entered by independent observers, including journalists, not party to the election. This impacted directly on the transparency of the electoral process and the perceived credibility of the electoral procedures. Commonly accepted as an international norm, this feature was curiously absent from the Hong Kong system. As a result, the observer mission assessments had to be made on the basis of interviews with voters after they emerged from the polling booth, with party booth workers and with the occasional election day official who ventured outside the booth.

There are also issues relating to the administration of the electoral process. The principal administrator of the electoral law and election process is the Constitutional Affairs Office of the Hong Kong Government. It has been suggested that this should be replaced by an independent electoral commission which would be responsible for the impartial administration of the electoral process. Like the previously mentioned Boundaries Commission, this body would be able to protect the Government from accusations of manipulation and establish a higher level of perceived credibility to the process. As the need for this type of high-profile electoral administration is still very new, the machinery and its form and function are still ill-defined and unpractised. The matter of an independent electoral commission should be looked at carefully in the review of the September Legislative Council election.

The common law and the role of the courts also require consideration. The courts act as the principal dispute resolution mechanism within the electoral system. The solid respect for the law and the common law legal tradition in Hong Kong are very applicable in establishing useful guidelines in the matters discussed above. There is an election chamber in the High Court which has begun to hear cases involving the electoral law. Problems have arisen within the electoral system and have been dealt with expeditiously and fairly.

Recently, a judge heard the case of Emily Lau and Simon Ip, two candidates in the September 1991 election. Both had inadvertently left the name of the printer and the print date off their posters or printed leaflets, contrary to a long-standing law designed to facilitate the prosecution of libel cases. Without legislation governing campaigning per se, this law was discovered by the candidates to be applicable to their printed materials. The judge upheld the candidates with no contest from the Government or other candidates. Thus the court system worked with the current electoral code and allowed it to operate fairly. There is no guarantee of such in the future. Thus, it is widely recognised that segments of the law require legislative remedy to be more effective.

The Government of Hong Kong has stated its intention to conduct a thorough review of the electoral law and related regulations after the election. All aspects of the electoral process and its legal framework should be considered in this comprehensive review. The electoral ordinance and regulations, the corrupt practices law, the election administration machinery and the status of political parties should all be addressed.

As Hong Kong is one of the most sophisticated and international of all cities, the development of a political framework in Hong Kong will undoubtedly be of interest to people from many parts of the world. It was beyond the scope and purpose of the observer mission to make judgments or comments about the appropriate structure for this future development; nevertheless, individually, I was obviously able to reach some conclusions in this regard. As has already been indicated, the main point at issue in the election, especially between the major parties, was Hong Kong's future relationship with the People's Republic of China and, most especially, the extent to which democracy will be established in Hong Kong before 1997 and be allowed to remain or further develop after the Chinese takeover.

Undoubtedly, there is considerable continuing unease in Hong Kong about 1997. This was reflected in a public opinion poll conducted during the election campaign which showed that only 22 per cent of respondents wanted Hong Kong to return to China, with the remaining 78 per cent fairly evenly split between wanting to remain a British colony, wanting to become an independent member of the Commonwealth of Nations or wanting to become a completely independent republic.

The enthusiasm and specific comments of voters I interviewed at various polling booths on election day left me in no doubt that they have a real commitment to full democracy and to its role in Hong Kong's future stability and prosperity.

The voting figures showed overwhelming support for candidates supporting greater democracy before the Chinese takeover. Those who had been most vocal in these demands, the United Democrats, won 12 seats and their close allies, Meeting Point, won a further two--14 of the 18 seats up for grabs. The Association for Democracy and People's Livelihood won a seat and Independents won three seats; candidates sympathetic to China polled very poorly.

The election results, combined with the opinion poll result, must lead us to question the wisdom of Britain's decision to hand Hong Kong back to China. The fact that Hong Kong was part of China until the mid-nineteenth century is no valid reason for that situation to be restored for the twenty-first century and beyond. Many international boundaries have changed and not been restored over much shorter periods. However, given the agreement reached between Britain and China, plus China's general attitude on these matters, it is probably unrealistic to expect any change now. But the election result should lead democrats throughout the world to agitate for full democracy, that is, a fully directly elected Legislative Council with an executive responsible to it to be in place before the change of sovereignty in 1997.

The Basic Law should be redrafted, as advocated by Martin Lee, MLC, who obtained about 70 per cent of the vote in his constituency, and others to reflect more closely the Joint Declaration. It is up to Britain to take note of the election results and negotiate these changes with China. The British Government should summon its resolve and act urgently on these issues.

Given China's unsatisfactory human rights record, as documented by the recent Australian Human Rights delegation, the Australian Government should use its influence with Britain to press for these changes in Hong Kong to be initiated. The Government should also use Australia's solid relations with China to persuade it to accept such changes.

It is in China's economic interests for Hong Kong to continue its important contribution as a source of investment and outlet for goods, especially for southern China. That will continue only if Hong Kong people have confidence that China will not interfere in the local administration of Hong Kong after 1997. Confidence in the future is the key to Hong Kong's continuing stability, prosperity and contribution to the mainland. Greater guarantees of democracy through changes to the Basic Law would ensure this confidence. It is therefore in China's interests to agree to this.

The Australian Government should clearly make these points to China. Changes will occur only through agreement between Britain and China, but the rest of the democratic world can bring its influence to bear on these two players to ensure a better deal is negotiated for Hong Kong and its residents up to and beyond 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Earlier today, the estimates for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade were before the Committee of the Whole of the Senate. The estimates had, of course, previously been considered by Estimates Committee B. I raised certain questions this morning relating to the estimates for the Department, including questions relating to human rights violations in China and Australia's overseas development assistance. Standing Orders prevent wide-ranging discussion and debate whilst the estimates are before the Committee of the Whole and therefore tonight I desire to place before the Senate a speech I gave to the Development Assistance Officers Association in Canberra on 25 July 1991 entitled Development Assistance Priorities: Professional Discernment or the Party Line. I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate that speech into Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows--

Thank you for the invitation to discuss with you human development issues. As members of the Development Assistance Officers Association you are the right people with whom to share these views and this is the right time (not like British Charge in Latin America). It sure takes something to get a Politician to Canberra for extra-Parliamentary duties in winter. A shared commitment to development assistance is the key. The record shows that, of all members of Parliament, I was the most outspoken critic of Budget cuts to ODA last year and the shift in priorities. So I am pleased and honoured to be among you.
DEVELOPMENT
Enabling the true human development of each individual can be seen as the main objective of society, and therefore of political and economic systems.

Individuals and families are the core of society. Their well being is therefore central to the political and economic processes which seek to promote development. There is no sound and authentic development of a society unless priority is given to the needs of the individuals and families within that society. To the extent that any action taken is not in the real interests of individuals and families, then it is not contributing to true human development.

The totalitarian ideologies of fascist and communist States sought to develop societies at the expense of the rights of individuals and families. They failed to acknowledge that the family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society with pre-eminent rights and functions. They have been condemned by their victims and by history. Only by respecting the rights and values of the subjects of development can a solid framework for economic and social development assistance be laid.
ROLE OF AID

Australians and the citizens of other economically advanced states recognise to a greater or more often, sadly, a lesser degree their duty to assist the development of others. This duty stems from our solidarity with the rest of humanity as well as from our self interest as a nation.

My own interests in this area developed really as an extension of my Union work and my recognition of the need for worker solidarity. [TTLC Rule Changes--Objects clause, ACTU, ILO, Role of Co-ops, workers rights, unemployment and under employment, poverty, Africa, PNG].

In over 30 years of work in Unions and politics I have witnessed many political foul ups--some with disastrous consequences. From my observations I have concluded that these were caused not so much by a lack of good will, a lack of information, a lack of expertise, as much as by a lack of discernment.

The goal of discernment is to arrive, in the light of permanent principles, at an objective judgement about social reality and, according to the possibilities and opportunities offered by the circumstances, to make concrete the most appropriate choices which may eliminate injustices and favour the political, economic and cultural transformations needed in particular cases. Discernment and the evaluation of truth leads to the investigation of the real causes of social ills, and especially of injustice, and to the acceptance of certain results, not the ideologised ones, of the human sciences (see A Vous Tous).

So often the blind adherence to an ideological party line or to what is sometimes called the "prevailing consensus" or "prevailing view" militates against this discernment. This is exacerbated by a lack of humility which is endemic amongst many of us politicians and, dare I say, some public servants.

It has proved quite difficult for Governments to devise and implement programmes to assist the people of our own country despite the fact that parliamentarians and public servants do work hard to try to ensure we get these things right.
It is even harder though to successfully intervene in someone else's country in assisting them to help their own people work towards a more advanced stage of development. This is a daunting task.

It really does call for maturity and discernment particularly in respect of those programmes which work to change societal values in recipient countries, which have social engineering elements and long lasting effects. Australian taxpayers money is used to support some of these programmes in collaboration with self serving international bureaucracies. Of course "consultation" with or without implied threats takes place with elites in recipient countries many of whom have been the intellectual victims of the "institutional strengthening" tactics of these same bureaucracies by means of which they ensure their view prevails.
In seeking to successfully intervene in someone else's country Governments and their advisers must examine the effects of their own attitudes and policies on Australia and its people.

It is a sobering thought that as the former Treasurer said, Australia is in danger of becoming a banana republic. Our gross foreign debt is over 165 billion dollars, unemployment is rising and underemployment burgeoning. Compared with only 9 years ago there has been a 30% increase in the number of young people suiciding; statistically one in every three new marriages will end in divorce; for every three live births one unborn child is deliberately destroyed by abortion--a higher rate than UK, NZ or USA, and the perinatal death rate in the Northern Territory is over twice the national average.
A realistic sense of humility in the face of domestic policy failure is surely called for when policy decisions are made about overseas aid programmes and priorities.
Yes this daunting task is one which AIDAB staff initially need to face.
Official aid programmes operate under a number of constraints which probably make that task even more difficult than it is in theory.
ROLE OF PUBLIC SERVANTS IN POLICY FORMULATION

In terms of today's rediscovery of "ethics", I support Dr John Uhr's views that "The real heart of administrative ethics is the ethics of public accountability . . . .. accountability to the "authorised scrutineers", i.e. the elected representatives of the people.

Public servants carry a heavy responsibility, especially when they work on policy issues. They are accountable to the Minister, but they also carry a broader accountability to the Parliament and the Australian people. This is particularly the case where the policies have long term or irrevocable repercussions as aid programmes almost inevitably do.

The Public Servants are clearly not employed to pursue their own narrow interests, in a policy sense or in any other way, at the expense of the human rights and interest of the people they serve. And they, perhaps more than their counterparts who are employed by private organisations, need to discern the common good as well as the good of their particular organisation or of their boss at the time.

An organisation in a field where the risks are high needs to be able to admit mistakes, and to be up-front about where the risks lie, and where mistakes have been made--and I don't mean only admitting to classic foul ups like coconut factories in Tonga or land resettlements in Kenya!

Operating in the public domain in a number of countries as AIDAB does, there is also the requirement to provide relevant and accurate information to interested parties, including, of course, members of parliament. I must acknowledge the strenuous efforts of AIDAB staff to discharge this duty to Democracy. It would not inspire confidence to see information having to be dragged out of an organisation at Estimates or wherever when common sense as well as the rights and duties of all involved would require that it should be given freely to a Member of Parliament in the first place.

It would become painfully obvious to observers and participants alike that an organisation which could not manage to get accurate information to interested parliamentarians in its own country would have even greater difficulty in consulting effectively with those affected by its programmes in other countries.
One area about which information is lacking are reports and evaluations by AIDAB on those International organisations which are supported by Australian taxpayers funds.

Serious questions need to be raised about their accountability and their pursuit of a party line to the exclusion of professional discernment. [Examples: WHO/UNDP/UNFPA/World Bank/HRP Programme; Abortion drug RU486--Who/why/how promoted; other human pesticides; gilding the picture e.g. "unmet demand"; fraudulent researcher Briggs--WHO/HRP adviser; role of pharmaceutical companies; IPPF tactics of "institutional strengthening" and censorship of opposing views e.g. IPPF's threatened liable action against Trombley book "the enforced withdrawal of this book reduces much needed discussion of the issues involved"--Lancet 8/4/89; instructions to researchers to ignore ill effects of "modern" contraceptives--Indonesia; pressures on countries to establish abortion practices e.g. Ireland where abortion is illegal and where the influence of "family planning" organisations has until recently been minimal yet maternal and child health is amongst the best in the world.]

Again the World Bank too often seems to be out of the control of its member Governments. One reads regularly of their "policy dialogue" with developing countries having the appearance of a type of international bullying. From discussions with American congressmen I find that they have much greater access to documentation on World Bank projects and on issues than is apparently available in Canberra. This is very obvious on environmental matters, where Congress seems to have played a very significant role in focussing the interests of sections of the US populace. It is also apparent in relation to abortion funding, where figures such as Congressman Henry Hyde seek to ensure that US taxpayers money is not used in ways those taxpayers consider inimical to their interests. There is a long way to go before Australian public servants provide the sort of information that their US counterparts do to the Congress. But why should the Australian people and their elected representatives be denied such full and complete information. I suspect that the relevant documents are frequently not held by Treasury or AIDAB--let alone the priority given for the constant and detailed evaluations of Australian taxpayer supported international organisations and their programmes which public accountability demands.
AUSTRALIA'S HUMAN RIGHTS INTERESTS

One clearly enunciated principle of Australian foreign policy is that we consider the exercise of basic human rights by individuals in a society to be an essential part of that society's overall well being. In its dealings with other countries, Australia has a keen interest in promoting this commitment to human rights. The aid programme cannot be an exception to this.

I am not talking here about using aid as a stick with which to beat other countries around the head on human rights grounds. But there is a more modest approach to the question I am confident finds favour with the vast majority of Australia ; that our aid must not be used in ways which adversely affect the basic human rights of others.Not that there is evidence that this happens much. But there are some sorry examples--made worse by the feeble attempts to explain that any untoward consequences of this aid is somehow not the responsibility of the Australian Government; that the concept of "coercion" varies with national and cultural settings; that "respected" international organisations such as the World Bank, WHO, UNFPA, etc. support the programme.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has shown himself to be a supporter of Australia taking a high profile and a principled stand on the universality of human rights--an approach to international relations having solid backing within the Parliament.

On a number of occasions I found myself arguing with him that for a State to interfere with the conjugal relationships of a couple and to apply coercion to dissuade that couple from having children is a breach of fundamental human rights. I have reason to believe that the Minister now agrees with me. In May he stated publicly that he shares my distaste for anything in the nature of coercion associated with population programmes. This approach is in accord with the sentiment of the electorate, as well as with common sense. To argue, as I have heard, that it is not coercion to deprive the children of "offending" families access to education, or to discriminate against them in such areas as housing or income or to violate their parents' rights as workers etc is to take an ideologically driven stance that ranks basic human rights at a lower level than a Government's policy of reducing births. It seemed to me that in this area some Australian public servants have been saved by the Minister from inflicting their own views on Australia's highly regarded international stance on human rights issues. There are many among my colleagues and in the general community who will be watching for any attempt under the new Ministerial arrangements to undermine this stance.

A recent launch by the new Minister for Trade and Overseas Development of "Population and Development" briefing pack for Parliamentarians paid for by AIDAB raised a few eyebrows. This pack is based on one prepared by a London based population control organisation--the Marie Stopes International. Significantly Marie Stopes was a eugenicist who lobbied Parliamentarians to act to curtail "breeding" amongst the "C3" population because of its burden on the "A1" population. Coming from that stable it is not surprising that the pack uses almost exclusively material from organisations driven by the population control ideology, accepts uncritically their "research", abjectly fails to address legitimate and growing concerns over human rights violations; repeats the population controllers' ideological party line on coercion which attacks the permanent and indivisible nature of human rights and paves the way for those violations of human rights and workers' rights about which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has expressed concern, and finally is tinged with bigotry. One can only assume that the Minister had not read the pack prior to launching it. Marie Stopes advocated the sterilisation of the "feeble minded"--a theme taken up with cruel vigour by the Nazi regime. In his response at the time to population controllers and eugenecists such as Marie Stopes, G K Chesterton pilloried the bullying of bureaucracies and the terrorism of tenth rate professors.

Crucial to upholding the human rights of individuals and families is the understanding and the taking note of the views of the people you are looking to assist. This is, at least in theory, an important element in the approach taken to Government activity within Australia, and it should be a central part of the way that we implement our overseas aid programme. As Atticus put it to Scout:
"You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view--until you climb into his skin and walk around in it
Or, as Bishop Kenneth Crag more loftily observed:

"The first task in approaching another people, another culture, another religion, is to take off your shoes for the place we are approaching is holy. Else we will find ourselves treading on people's dreams. More seriously still we may forget that God was there before our arrival.
This then raises questions about a lot of activity that seeks to change the views or the practices of the supposed beneficiaries of aid so that they match up more with the views of the donors.

This sort of cultural imperialism seems to be an occupational hazard in the aid field. It has a long history. Much of our early treatment of the aboriginal population, and much of the colonial sentiment generally, was concerned with trying to impose a set of cultural values that were in fact the values of the wealthier or more powerful party. And cultural imperialism goes on.
POPULATION ISSUES
Cultural imperialism is perhaps as its modern day height on population matters.

Some years ago one used to read of economic analyses purporting to demonstrate the sense of population control programmes. The costs of these programmes were the measured costs of the various inputs. Benefits were claimed to include the costs that would have had to be incurred in educating, housing, etc the children that might have been born had the population control programme not taken place. This approach was obviously skewed in that it measured what it would cost to raise the children but it did not include the benefits they would bring. What seems to have been responsible for closing down this approach is that it dawned on observers that, if there were benefits in having fewer people, then the most cost effective way of going about the exercise would be to kill them off.
This result is abhorrent, but it flows from the assumption that there are clear net benefits in having fewer people.
The question also needs to be asked : benefits to whom? To the heavy consumer of energy etc in richer countries? To the Government? To the rest of the community?

The tunnel vision of the international population control lobby became evident at the U.S. Senate convened meeting of Parliamentarians on the Global Environment which I attended in Washington last year. One delegate said how "shocking" it was that people continued to breed so much in Ghana. Surely it is inhuman to describe as "shocking" the increase in the number of Ghanans, Nigerians, Kenyans, Indians or of any other people and to infer that the world would be a nicer and altogether a cleaner place without them. The population controllers are proven pessimists and fail to appreciate the creative spirit with which we are endowed. Who is to say that from amongst those people included in the "shocking" increase there will not come inventors and leaders with the gifts to enable 10 billion people to live in a more environmentally friendly way than 5 billion?

What is shocking is the promotion of population control policies which develop an unwelcome anti-child mentality which will enable governments, even in developed countries, to pursue anti-child and anti-family policies.

In fact the origins of our environment problems are to be found in a disrespect for life in all its forms--especially human life. The population control mentality will entrench this destructive attitude.

The question needs to be asked: can a social or economic measure be analysed only in terms of its impact on those currently living? Much environmental analysis is couched in terms of the impact of measures on future generations. This implies that there is some value in future generations, which of course there is. But much of the analysis of population issues does not recognise this. It counts the birth of a child as a drain on the economy, but the birth of a calf as a benefit--which means that it employs a type of logic that does not make sense to most of the world's population.

So, population control programmes are based on an analysis that is faulty. They are also aimed at overturning the values of the people who are targeted. One comes across this time and time again in reports from other countries : in much of Africa, in China, in India, in Eastern Europe, etc. and now in PNG. Programmes are developed by foreigners to alter the value systems of local populations.

One of the most disconcerting aspects of following the population controllers' ideological party line is that in addition to diverting funds away from primary health care it diverts attention from the real problems of poverty and their solutions. I would like to quote a brief relevant section of my speech to the abovementioned conference.

"It is evident that the population control lobby is attempting to use, for its own agenda, world-wide concern for the environment. Their assertions that population growth is a crucial negative factor in economic development and their dire predictions of resource exhaustion have long since been proved wrong.

Their fatal diagnosis is that people growth in developing countries is the problem and that population control is the solution. This diagnosis is deceptive, simplistic and distracts attention from the real problems and their solutions. The population control lobby cannot trust parents to make responsible decisions governing their intimate relationships and the size of their families. It says that these decisions must be heavily influenced by the population policies of politicians at the behest of outside agencies and by governments no matter how dictatorial.

As parliamentarians, we must be ever wary of the attempts by non-elected bureaucratic elites to steer meetings of parliamentarians in their predetermined direction. Over many years, the population control lobby has sought to use international fora to promote a so-called `consensus' on this issue and to use it to promote their ideology of population control imperialism.

The fertility of poor women in developing countries has been made the scapegoat for a range of problems from environmental damage to famine, the primary causes of which are war, political instability and man's inhumanity to man. To propose population control as the panacea is to succumb to the pessimism of our age. To point the finger of guilt at the fertility of poor women is to set the stage for policies which discriminate against the families of less developed countries and to open the way for gross violations of human rights. The present unhealthy fixation on population control is economically and socially naive and dangerous. It diverts the attention and efforts of governments in both the developed and developing world away from the real and pressing measures required.

As parliamentarians, we need to shed pessimism and exude hope to work for a fair world trading and exchange system, to reduce indebtedness and unemployment, to assist with making fisheries and farming more attractive, to exchange technologies, to promote the environmentally sound and efficient use of resources, to reform inefficient or corrupt economic practices, to promote human initiatives to feed the poor; in short, to strive for an authentic socioeconomic development based on social justice and respect for human life. Faced with evidence which has destroyed the pessimistic forecast of the population control lobby, it is now using world concern for the environment to promote its viewpoint".
A POSITIVE APPROACH

In fact, as I mentioned at the outset, society and development revolve around individuals. Human rights, human development, and societal well being all relate primarily to the individuals and family and other groups that go to make up the society. Any analysis that ignores this is in trouble, and any programme of development that ignores it is doomed to failure.
In the high risk business of international aid, we should be supporting approaches to development that build on this important role of the individual and of primary groups such as the family.
We should be supporting development activities that involve a shared set of values between ourselves and the people whom we are trying to assist.

And we should identify opportunities for collaboration in areas where we can be sure that the interests of the individuals who are supposed to benefit coincide with the interests of good Government. AIDAB should be proud of many of its programmes in achieving all of this, for example, in the areas of training aid, humanitarian relief, agricultural research etc. and one hopes, in the provision of infrastructure, etc. The challenge for AIDAB and for Australia generally is to ensure that all elements of its development assistance programmes and priorities support true human development. This task needs to be approached by the pathway of mature discernment unblinkered by an ideological party line.

If there are some of you whose immediate mental reaction to my being invited here was one of surprise bordering on resentment perhaps you might care to examine whether your judgements are indeed coloured by a party line--a prevailing view which unprofessionally censors out other views. For the rest I thank you for your invitation for asking me to this luncheon and to all of you for listening to what I have had to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have spoken in this chamber for quite some time trying to bring to the notice of parliamentarians in Canberra the plight of people in rural communities. Because of the drought, many Australians face a worse plight than ever before. I believe that those people who travel from city electorates get very isolated from the reality of what happens in many of the country areas, and I do not think that they quite understand the extent of the problems. That is why this morning I moved a notice of motion in which I said that the Senate should note:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) the visit to Canberra from parents from the Isolated Children Parents' Association (ICPA),

(ii) that this group represents 10,000 Australian children who are disadvantaged through inadequate and inequitable funding policies of the Hawke Labor Government simply because they live in rural and remote areas of Australia,
(iii) that the education of many of these children is seriously at risk because of the critical economic recession in rural parts of Australia,
(iv) that many children will be forced to finish their schooling early, simply because parents have neither the resources to send them to school nor the time to teach them at home, and
(v) that this will exacerbate the growing pool of rural unskilled unemployed . . .
I called upon the Federal Government to address the ICPA's very real concerns and introduce strategies to avoid even more serious unemployment levels in rural areas.

Some case studies have been given to me which I would like to go through very quickly. They tear at my heart and I hope some of those people sitting opposite, and some of those sitting on this side of the chamber also, will understand what is happening in some of the rural and remote areas of Australia.

For example, Family C lives on a specialist sheep and wool property in the western division in New South Wales. The eldest child boards with his grandmother in order to attend high school. Two children are at home being taught by correspondence by the mother, who also has a small child. At the end of 1990 the property was auctioned and failed to attract one bid, and it would be even less likely to do so now. The banks have valued the place at $130,000 and the family owes $150,000. The family's wool cheque dropped from $100,000 last year to $70,000, and the major supply of stock water--a bore--collapsed, creating another debt of $47,000 as a new water supply had to be put in to look after the animals and the people who live there.

The family has lived on a family allowance supplement since April 1991, which is $650 a month, including the family allowance. With the wool floor price abolished and stock worth nothing, no money has been drawn from the property since the end of 1990. The father goes shooting as a licensed shooter when he can. The FAS plus the AJC allowance of $250 a month buys the family's food and clothing and pays for the child's board at his grandmother's. Due to the severe drought and loss of stock, the shearing this year will make only $20,000. The mother also makes straw hats when she can to make extra money. There is much hardship in that example.

Family D lives in far western New South Wales on a sheep and wool property and is isolated from any schooling. The property is suffering an extreme drought and since shearing in May has lost 1,500 to 2,000 sheep. The family averaged $1,200 a bale in 1988 but, with the collapse of the price of wool, this year received $365 a bale. Due to the recession the mother has moved to Broken Hill to go into the teaching profession in order to assist with finances, and the three children are with her, which means that the family has been split up, except during school holidays. Every couple of weeks the youngest child, who is four, travels 300 kilometres on a bus to go home to spend a few days with the father, to assist with the feeding of the stock during the drought and to be his secretary and answer the phone.

I have another case history. This family has six children and is very isolated, living in the Peninsula region on a cattle property in difficult country. It costs something like $100 per head merely to get the stock to market. Three of the children are in the work force: two attend agricultural college and one is an apprentice. One is at school with a university career planned and one is at home studying via primary correspondence. The husband is in Western Australia working and the wife has a job in the local town. They still owe for their children's schooling--even though they have long since left school--as well as for the child who now attends boarding school. They pay the school a few hundred dollars at a time whenever they have a spare dollar, and the school is very supportive and has faith that they will pay off all the debt in due time. They have cattle agisted on their property and the owner of the cattle keeps an eye on the place for them. These case studies are just three examples of families who are in a lot of trouble and who are being separated and torn apart by the problems occurring in the rural areas.

I have yet another case history. A family manages a property north of Julia Creek. The family has two daughters at boarding school. They have to drive 570 kilometres to a bus run or 670 kilometres directly to school, so they normally drive straight to the school. The school costs are as follows: school fees and incidentals, $8,000 per child, which means it costs that family $16,000; travel, $2,000 per child, which means a total of $4,000; and tax, $13,000. That makes a total of $33,000. The family receives a reimbursement of $2,500 per child GMP and LAFH, and a reimbursement for travel of $1,260. Tax and educational costs total $26,740. The money left for the family to live on is something like $5,620 a year, and the family has taken one daughter away from school.

People might ask, `Why are you bringing this up in the Senate?'. The point is that if people in those remote areas are driven away from those areas and if we say, `Right-oh, we are not going to give any assistance to those people in those remote areas', vast areas of Australia will be uninhabited; we will go back to what it was like prior to white settlement. We will have neglect and decay. Our land--both the soil and the environment--will deteriorate if people do not live in those areas. We will have an horrific loss of native animals--for example, kangaroos, which have proliferated since white settlement because of the water supplies that have been established in many areas.
This information comes from a document signed by a regional officer of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture, which states:

The Rural Counsellors have indicated that the stress on the families is having a very traumatic effect on many marriages and their family life and the children's lives. Nervous breakdowns are being experienced, in particular the men and the counsellors have indicated the women are keeping the family unit together and bearing the brunt of these disastrous situations.

It is estimated that in an area from the top end of the central west to the far west of New South Wales, between 25 per cent and 30 per cent of landowners will have to walk off their properties with nothing but a lot of heartbreaks to show for their life on the land.

It is a concern to me, and it should be a concern to all Australians, that this is happening. The people from the Isolated Children's Parents Association who were here today have made a representation to me and they will be making a representation to the Government tomorrow. I know that Senator Tate is a thinking and feeling person, and I hope that these people are received well. I hope that a lot of their problems are properly accommodated. I have already made the point about the money which is owed to boarding schools. One school and two hostels have already closed because the costs are up and government grants and enrolments are down. The schools were situated in New Norcia in Western Australia--your area of Australia, Mr Deputy President--and Southport in Queensland, and the hostel was Griffith hostel in New South Wales.

One should remember that the Government of this country has just signed the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, which includes the right to education. A lot of people in those remote areas are being denied fair and equitable access to education, and that is something we should all be looking at. These people are not asking for assistance of any great magnitude; they are just asking for a fair go. This is exemplified very clearly in a document from the Isolated Children's Parents Association, which states:
Non metropolitan people are entitled to equitable access to education and training at a personal cost comparable to that of metropolitan people.

I refer to what happened when we had a real natural disaster--an earthquake--in Newcastle. The people there were still able to send their children to school the next day even though they might not have had a house, because there were still buses or they had other access to the schools.

I say to the Senate and the Parliament of Australia that we should give the people in the bush a fair go and make sure that we give them a full and proper hearing. Let us make sure that we keep people living in those remote areas because they are the salt of the earth.
